reviews.review_text: I've been playing Path of Exile since 2011 closed beta and it's remarkable how far the game has come purely from crowd funding. The passion of the userbase is equally matched by it's developers. They've shown throughout the years to constantly improve and tweak the game with regularly scheduled content additions. I still feel I don't know everything there is to know about this game, and that isn't changing any time soon. Path of Exile is an incredibly complex and rewarding game that is definitely worth your time.  Outside of having an absurdly intricate skill tree and a fantastic crafting/currency system, the other large appeal of this game is the end-game. Most ARPGs fail to offer incentive to continue to play your character after you've exhausted the content. Usually this just comes in the form of a easily attainable level cap or grinding the same final zone of the game at length. Instead, in POE you are given item drop instances, as described by the developers:   'Maps can drop as normal, magic, rare or unique with higher rarity Maps yielding more items. Using a Map item opens six portals to the area, which can each only be used once. Like most other items in Path of Exile, Maps have mods that change their risks and rewards. Map mods can affect the size or complexity of the level, monster packs, monster properties or even alter characters while in the level. Players can modify Maps themselves using their currency items. For example, you can use an Orb of Transmutation to turn a normal Map into a magic Map, or use an Orb of Alteration to reroll its mods.'  It goes to say that each and every map is a different experience, with room for countless variation in modifiers letting you push the limits of your character. Not all characters are equal. You will find that some characters that excell in early progression have difficulty in the end-game and visa versa. Each character I've made has informed the next which is critical in a game that rewards experience and skill.  And if that wasn't enough, POE offers alternative ARPG experiences in the form of daily race events which are time based leveling with unique modifiers that you won't see in the real game like 'Turbo Mode'. Moreover some of these races have entirely unique content like Descent: Champions or Endless Ledge which offer players the ability to win special art reskins of legendary items for the leagues of their choice.  All in all POE is a truly exciting game and a breath of fresh air for the genre.

The best isometric aRPG I've ever played... and it's free. That should be enough to get you to try the game; a character-limit in-depth review follows:  OVERVIEW  A top-down isometric action RPG. This genre has for many years been called 'Diablo clones', and no doubt the game feels like Diablo -- questing, levelling up, finding gear, and using skills to kill stuff -- but the systems behind the gameplay are really well thought out, and especially the skill system is much deeper than any other aRPG.  Path of Exile is completely, utterly free. And don't let this dissuade you from trying it, because I think it's the best isometric aRPG I've ever played. Microtransaction cash offers no competitive advantage in the game, just cosmetic enhancements, extra stash tabs, and character slots. So if the game sounds interesting, just try it for yourself! But meanwhile, here's why you should:  STORY  Okay, let's be honest: This probably isn't a game you're playing for the story. Without the huge budget of a Blizzard Entertainment, you're not going to get 3-minute epic cutscenes that draw you in with movie quality. Grinding Gear Games seems to have focused on making the game good instead, and I support that decision. That being said, the underlying narrative isn't bad per se, just fairly standard and doesn't really distinguish itself.  GRAPHICS  The graphics are perfectly good for my purposes. They look decent, even if they didn't blow me away in the fully zoomed out mode. They actually look pretty good zoomed in, but of course when enemies can attack you from offscreen even fully zoomed out, nobody is going to play zoomed in. Regardless, the graphics made the game much more gritty. While Diablo went cartoonish, and Torchlight was brightly colored and animated, the world of Wraeclast is dark and dangerous, and everything in the game re-enforces that harshness. Levels are nicely differentiated: cavernous dungeons, a waste of sunken ships, temples of polished marble, rocky cliffs, forests, etc. Some of the dungeons are really downright creepy. As are some enemies. Heck, even your hero -- You are a criminal, an exile, and as such are portrayed with a harsh ugliness that works pretty well. Other minor things show attention to detail, like arrows sticking out of enemies or walls after you fire them. While the graphics may not impress on a technological level, the art direction here is well done.  (I'm also led to believe that various spell effects become a lot more impressive-looking if you buy a microtransaction.)  SOUND  I didn't really notice the sound. And I think that's not a bad thing; while it would be nice to have music tracks that really blew me away, other than that I tend to think good sound in a game is like good service at a restaurant -- mostly invisible, because it delivers what you need without belaboring the point. Creepy areas felt creepy, spiders skittered, armor clanked, spell effects were satisfying, and perhaps most importantly, commentary from my character was just frequent enough to be interesting. I easily tire of games where my character blathers on every third minute with the same tired catchphrases. Likewise, there was never any lull in music where the game felt too silent, nor irritating track repeated so often that an annoying melody got stuck in my head. So I'll again say the sound is perfectly fine; unlikely to impress, but no negative marks here either.  GAMEPLAY MECHANICS  Ah, finally the thing that matters most, and the reason you should be downloading this game right now. The fighting itself is fairly standard aRPG; click on things and push letters to use various skills to attack the enemies. There's more strategy than that, because you can drop traps and totems and have forking and radius skills etc. etc. But the systems behind all of this game are what put Path of Exile far ahead of the pack. So let's talk about them. There are a lot of small things that show some thought behind the game, from the various loot settings, to the ease of dropping into pick-up groups, to the simple way instances are handled, to the large 4-tabbed stash shared between all of your characters. But the main gameplay innovations, the reasons Path of Exile is the game I've been playing non-stop for weeks on end, can be divided into two main categories: Skills, and Economy.  SKILLS  Skills in Path of Exile are complex. The briefest way to describe it is that their active skills were inspired by Final Fantasy VII, and their passive skills by Final Fantasy X. But that would be far from giving you the whole story.  So, the first thing to explain is that any character can gain any skill. Your class determines starting stats and starting location in the 'Skill Forest'. Every active skill exists in the form of a gem that is red (str), green (dex), or blue (int). Gear has sockets of those colors to hold gems. When a gem is placed into your gear, you now have that skill. Skill gems can be removed at any time, so no worries about experimenting. Some gear has linked sockets, allowing you to equip support gems that augment other linked gem skills. Equipped gems gain experience over time, and you can choose to level them up, raising their power, but also raising the stat requirements. So any character can use any skill, but it will be tougher for a Marauder to use a level 15 Firestorm than it will for a Witch.   Each time you level up, you will receive one passive skill point to spend in the Skill Forest. The Skill Forest contains something like 1,350 nodes. No, that's not a typo. There are 1,350 places to spend skill points. So even if you maxed out your character after a year of playing to the highest level, you'd have covered less than 1/10 of the grid.  There are basic +10 to a stat nodes, and your character will start near many of their favored stat, although you can follow a path anywhere you like. There are nodes to improve spellcasting, movement, accuracy, damage, and so on. At various places on the grid, there are clusters of nodes that grant bonuses to each weapon type or elemental damage type. Some nodes add life, evasion, or energy shield. Some nodes add resists, block rates, or criticals. Bigger nodes are fewer and farther between, but each one gives a benefit generally more than twice as good as a standard small node.   And then there are keystone nodes. These giant circular nodes around the edges of the grid tend to be huge trade-offs that completely change your character. Eldritch Battery removes your character's energy shield, converting it entirely to extra mana. Chaos Innoculation reduces your life to 1, but makes you immune to chaos(poison) damage. Either one will change your character drastically; taking both will kill you. Other skills remove your armor, your evasion, or even your ability to deal damage with active skills, offering various trade-offs in return.  Anyway, the skill system is incredibly complex, and while there are thankfully respec points you can gain by questing in game (and more from certain loot), it's worth pre-planning skills.  ECONOMY  Path of Exile has no gold.  Because there is no accumulating pile of money, there is no money sink of repairs or potions. (Flasks are equipment items that refill automatically as you kill enemies, and can be enchanted.) Vendoring items nets you various orbs, and vendor items have orb purchase prices. But the key difference is that everything has inherent value. Orbs do not just accumulate uselessly like gold in many of these games, because every orb has inherent value. They improve your items in different ways, allowing you to enchant your new hybrid flask, reroll the enchantment on your boots, and reroll the number of sockets on your armor.   Crafting is complex.  CONCLUSION  Skill Forest is complex too. Path of Exile is aiming for hardcore gamers when other games are streamlining more casual. This is a game by gamers, for gamers, and it shows.

I could recommend this game for a good many reason, most of which I notice have already been mentioned by other reviewers. The best thing, for me, about this game is it's truly open-ended character building. You aren't squished into a rigid, constricted class. Granted, certain classes have certain bonuses to certain stats(ie, Maurader class starts with high strength stats), but beyond that you are perfectly free to build your character into whatever you want them to be. Skills are gained, not through grinding, leveling up and unlocking them, but by finding skill gems throughout the world. The gems fit into color-coded slots on your armor and weapons.  Some pros and cons:  Pros: -Free to Play but not Pay to Win -Easy enough to get into if you have the time. No real background in RPGs needed to enjoy this game. -Plenty, and I mean PLENTY to do. You will not be bored. -Maps are randomly generated labrynths. No dungeon will ever be the same twice. -(this could be a con depending on your tastes) hoards of monsters that inhabit each dungeon. Getting strong enough to mow them down like blades of grass is oh, so satisfying. -A unique barter system that cuts out gold or other currencies from the game. New players don't start out poor and feel they have to grind just to buy good gear. -Diablo style loot system. You're going to find the best stuff out there in the game world, not in an NPC's shop. -(Mostly personal preference here:) No constantly buying potions. Flasks that fill with health potion or mana potion are found as drops ingame and are refilled each time you slay an enemy.  Cons: -If you like it, it will take over your life. -Definitely not casual. When you sit down to play, plan on spending at least two hours on one play session. -Quests become somewhat repetative. 'Go here, find this. Come back with something to prove it.' Sort of thing. Each dungeon being unique helps cut out any sense of monotony, though. -Waypoints are few and far between. At maximum, there is one per map. Some maps have multiple levels to them, and the waypoint exists only on one specific level. Some maps lack a waypoint entirely. -Won't run on a toaster. I tried downloading this game on my old windows 7 toaster, and the game never even made it past the loading screen.  Overall, especially considering the price tag, I am calling this my favorite rpg ever. The graphics are beautiful.The voice acting blew me away considering this is F2P. It's dark and mysterious. Even now that I feel I'm getting the hang of it, I still feel a sense of forboding whenever I enter a new portion of a dungeon. Some people might call this a Diablo cheap knock-off. Cheap? Well, only if you mean the price tag. It's a very well-thought-out and well-made game. Diablo knock-off? Maybe. It does borrow heavily from the Diablo franchise. I can't personally say how much as I don't play Diablo; but I notice the similarities whenever I watch a youtube video involving the Diablo games and for a moment think 'Hey, is that Path of Exile?'
It's so good, that I quit playing on steam six months ago so I wouldn't have to look at my hours played.

POE is basically an ARPG based loosely off the Diablo system. From what I have read about POE many old Diablo programmers are involved with POE and its gameplay mechanics. There are many saying that this is what Diablo 3 should be. I am not hear for that and would rather not compare the two, as I am one of the few who really enjoy Diablo 3. POE sports some interesting mechanics in gameplay as there is no gold or currency value in game or auction house of any sorts. Gems play a big part in leveling your gear and increasing stats. Inventory loadouts tend to fill quickly as you can not carry much. The locations and minions of POE universe are interesting and varied. POE has a rather dark tone to it with violent acts and blood.   I do have a gripe with sync/lag as it has been an issue for a while and that nano second where you dont get a hit or take damage in a ARPG is critical and this can be become frustrating. I do want to note that if you have not played this game yet and get started into it - the game starts very slowly and with very weak environments that are bland and a turn off. Many people have quit thinking this is what the game will be and it does indeed get more varied and graphically interesting... just need to play through a couple of realms first.  For a FTP game this is just an amazing game where I would be willing to pay actual money for it, so I will consider donating with some visual items you can buy directly through Steam in the POE micro transaction shops. These micro transactions are not pay to win and are cosmetic enhancements for the most part. In case you missed it - Gamespot announced POE as the PC Game of the Year. Recommended.

The Game : If you played Diablo 2, you know what to expect. Pick a character class and start pointing and clicking until you kill enough things to level up, gain more skills, and get better gear to kill more things! You build your character around the skills you choose to use, represented as gems that are slotted into your gear. As you level up, you put points into the massive (and I mean MASSIVE) passive skill tree to customize your character to how you want to play. The game runs through about level 36, Cruel difficulty to level 54, and Merciless to 68. The endgame (starting at level 66) consists of 'maps' that can drop from killing monsters.   Pros : Simple to learn, difficult to master. The enemies are diverse and always challenging, the maps are randomized, the skills are interesting and fun, and the loot system is incredibly well done. Joining friends is easy and fun. Did I mention the game is FREE?   Cons : The passive skill tree can be incredibly daunting to new players. There is no ability to respec your skills aside from starting over, so don't plan on your first character reaching the maps.   Conclusion : Play this game! It's simple to pick up and play at your own pace and consistently rewarding you for learning its more complex mechanics. Plus its free, the developer  ONLY  sells cosmetic items, so there is no possible way to gain a gameplay advantage by paying money unlike many other 'Free' to Play games out there (see: Neverwinter).
So basically you get a game with the depth that Diablo 3 should have had with the fun levels of torchlight? And I don't have to pay for it? Well Played, path of exile, well played!

edit: I use ggg's client mostly, on which I have logged most of my hours.  As Exalted/Champion/Master/Lunaris Supporter, who greatly admires the ethical business model of GGG and their title Path of Exile, my perspective is simply too biased. I advise you take anything I say with a massive grain of salt.  This is just a superb action role playing game. It is not for the faint of heart. It does not hold your hand with a tutorial. It expects you to put in some effort. It will be daunting at first. Very daunting.  Now the good news- It is not nearly as bad as it looks. That skill tree that looks ridiculously, gratuitously large and terrifying? Yeah, you'll have your bearings around that in a week or two. Probably less. Okay, so there's no gold, and you don't really get what that means? Neither did I... for two days, THEN you'll be Master of Coin, I promise. Two days, on the dot. Less if you drink energy drinks.   Yes Path of Exile is extremely complex. One of the most complex games you can find... but that doesn't mean you need to learn every little detail to become good, and it doesn't mean it's going to take a year for that to happen. Just jump in. It takes effort, sure. But the effort is fun and enjoyable, and you meet new friends along the way who are eager to help.   You're a hardcore gamer, amigo. You just don't know it yet. So come join us!  If you do, you will be greatly rewarded.  Welcome to the rabbit hole, friend. Now, down down down you fall, like many have before. And what lies ahead of you, I simply cannot summarize in review. But I cannot wait for you to experience like I did. Enjoy.  Lostman-  Edit: And I'm sure this is already known by readers, but this game is legitly free. There are no Pay2Win aspects. Many, many others have already said it, but at risk of sounding like a mindless parrot drone - this game is MUCH closer to what most Diablo fans wanted D3 to be (including myself). I won't necessarily say this game is what Diablo 3 should have been, but it's certainly not difficult for me to imagine that most people would have been much happier if it had turned out exactly like PoE has. As it states in the last bullet point in the 'Key Features' section: 'You cannot gain gameplay advantage by spending real money in Path of Exile.' This alone is such a massive gamechanger, and in a good way. I don't know about you, but I don't particularly tend to enjoy games which incorporate a 'pay to win' mentality. Sure it isn't absolutely necessary to shell out any additional cash to be sucessful in D3, but just the fact that it is an option eventually helped drive me and many others away. Also, let's be honest - the loot system in D3 was (and still is) horrendous and only serves to further the agenda of Diablo 3's Real Money Auction House (which they are finally going to do away with early next year along with most likely bettering your chances of finding good gear). Go figure that! Anyway I digress, this isn't about D3. I only mention it because if you intend to play an ARPG on the PC, it's probably going to be one of these two. What you need to know is that PoE offers a truly rewarding and deep experience throughout. Character development boasts outstanding flexibility and viability of unique builds with a complex and rich skill-point system coupled with ability gems that allow you to specifically tailor any class in the game to be played the way you prefer. Of course some work better than others, but that's just how it goes. In summation, whether you are tired of D3 and looking for your ARPG fix elsewhere or just plain want a fun new game to play in this genre, do yourself a favor and click 'Play Game.' After all, who needs to be convinced by reviews from strangers when you can experience it yourself for free?

Path of Exile is a Hack and Slash game, It's F2P and you basically get an full game for no price at all.   You can however spend some money to get some Pay 2 look damn good effects.  What they offer is: New Helmet models, Alternative Spell effects, small and cute pets and finally of what i know there are several kinds of Wing effects.   Anyways, to the basic works and system of the game.   The game is built on a Leveling system that gives your character one Passive skill point per level to put in an gigantic skill tree.   Wanna know how big this skill tree is? It's makes the FFXII licence board look like a little plate of NOTHING.   You got so many option on this tree, you could create a Witch that hacks people with axes and swords.   Or an big, strong and scary marauder that walk around casting fireballs with a wand that's only the size of his fingers.   That is what makes this game so awesome, you can do whatever you want.  Want a fire casting and teleporting necromancer that has an army of dead at his command? Go for it, works just fine.   And never forget to ask in the general chat for advice... Though sometimes you can get some.. odd answers.   I won't say to much, cuz that's not how i do.   Know this.. The game might be slow in the beginning, but when you reach the mid to higher levels... This turn into a crash fest of chopping, freezing, burning and exploding every foul dark creatures that stand in your way.  But never let your guard down... Anything can kill you if you're not carefull.  *Edit: They also gradually add more content to the game, Skills, areas, expansions, visual effects etc.  All i gotta say is i really think this game is awesome and that it's totally free, yet It's got better quality gameplay than most games that cost over 20 Euro to play.

*This review was for the 'Sacrifice of Vaal' It has since been updated (A lot) and I look forward to updating the review*  Hello Close friends and strangers of the internet, I'm back from Melbourne and, after 16 hours of gaming in the back seat of my car, feel the need to review the game 'Path of Exile.' Let's get started  I'd like to preface this review by saying that This Game Is Free. You've got nothing to lose by installing it.  'Path of Exile' is a Massive Multiplayer Online Role Playing Game (I could have said 'MMO RPG' but I sound like a legitimate game critic when I say it like that) Which I'm sure is a genre that we've all had our experiences in (Runescape, Rift Ect.) I have to say out of all the games I've played in this genre, this one is done very well. The mechanics are commendable but not overly different, the storyline and variation of the missions, average. The graphics aren't fantastic, but hey, it's a free game. What do you expect? I'm yet to try out the Co-op (Mainly because I have a serious lack of friends) But the duelling system is fairly balanced and fair and overall, games like this are just generally addicting  Now, I know your probably losing interest because this is sounding like every other MMO RPG but hold on, I'm getting to the good stuff  The best thing about this game is easily the passive skill tree. I know that sounds underwhelming but trust me, It could take days to plot a good path through this thing, I'm just trying to guess which direction I should head but in reality, this skill tree is so big it doesn't even fit on my computer screen. It's taken me 10 hours to figure out how the class and items work together (shown directly below.)  Forgive me if I’ve gotten this wrong, I've only played through the first act as a witch (Yeah, I'm still a noob)  I like to think of the class system as a colour wheel. There are 3 primary classes (one focused on intelligence, one on strength and one on dexterity) and 3 secondary classes, each one composed of 2 others (The duellist focuses on Strength and dexterity, the cleric focuses on strength and intelligence and the thief focuses on dexterity and intelligence.) These different classes all dictate where you start on the passive skill tree, shaped like a colour wheel. Most of the powerful items are clearly designed for a certain class as the all require a combination of the three traits (Intelligence, strength and dexterity) One that only requires intelligence is obviously designed for the person who is starts in the middle of the 'Intelligence' area in the passive skill tree Whereas an item that requires dexterity and strength is made for the class which is a combo of dexterity and strength.  Wow, that probably confused the F*ck out of you guys, it's really difficult to explain, it's so complex you could spend hours researching it.  The items all have combinations of 3 different traits (Wow, the developers must've really liked the number 3!) Evasion, energy shield and amour. Evasion determines how likely you are to dodge an attack, Amour determines how much of the damage is block and energy shield reminds me a lot of the 'overshield' from Halo or Mass Effect. It exists and if attacked, the energy shield is drained rather than your health. When the energy shield is depleted, you will have no defences other than your amour and evasion skills. The energy shield will restore after a period of not being attacked. However, your health will regenerate very slowly regardless of which items you wear. Each of the traits the amour has (Evasion, Amour and Energy shield) Link up to the traits the class has (Dexterity for Evasion, Amour for strength and Energy shield for intelligence) This is not a set rule but most items will have a requirement to meet.  Are you still following me? If you're not, it's okay. Even If I confused you, you’re probably noticing how in-depth this game is.  Finally, slots of amour have different coloured gem slots. There are three different coloured gems (So many ♥♥♥♥ING THREES!) And 3 different coloured gems (AHHHHHHH) which all link up to the 3 traits of the classes (I think I'm developing a '3' fetish) The red gems are usually for Melee combat, the green ones are for archery and the blue ones for magic. Some monsters resist certain types of these abilities, some resist fire, frost or lightning. Some monsters also can summon smaller units, perform similar abilities to what the player can perform and some monsters have energy shields.  Okay, I'm done. Thanks for reading if you made it this far. Click the like button if you did. I swear, it took ages to write this out and last review I did, not a single person liked it :(. I strongly recommend this game for all people who love a good MMO RPG. I would love to have one of my close friend (Jacob, Brodie, Dom, Josh, Lachlan, Sam, I'm looking at you guys.) to pick up this game so that I wouldn't have to continue this crazily confusing experience alone.   All in all, because it's a free game I'm giving it an 8.5/10

Now Path of Exile is a game that I have followed since it's early closed beta days and I've played since then too. This is one of the best Hack 'n Slash Action RPG games that you will find this year and what's more it is entirely free to play (yes a real free to play the only thing you pay real money for are cosmetics like extra gore, different skin on items so that you look a little unique, pets that do nothing but follow you or more warehouse slots etc).   The gameplay it self is pretty much Diablo 2 style. One amazing thing about the game to note is the skill tree and the way you can develop it... the possibilities are endless! Basically the skill tree is just passive skills while the spells and similar that you use to fight are 'gems' which you have to embed in your weapons/armors, what's more is that there are no class bound items so basically you can make a Ranger use staffs and use magic, a Marauder use bow and a Witch use a giant sword and that's not all, every single class has the same skill tree with the class being just the way you character looks and the starting possition in the skill tree.  The skills in this game are amazing. To use a skill you have to find a gem with that skill, meet the level and stat requerments and put it inside a gem slow in your weapon/armor. Each weapon/armor can have up to 4/6 slots with 3 different color and skill gems also have 3 different color types (based on Strength, Dexterity and Intelligence) and those slots on the weapon can be linked together so you can merge 2 or 3 different skills effects (using support gems with normal skills gems) to add new type of effects to your skills and make them even stronger. The crafting and currency systems in the game are really unique and awesome the normal currency used in other games like gold for example is totally removed and everything revolves around trading items and the currency items are the same as upgrade items (adding new options to you armor/weapons, socketing, changing their type from normal, magic, rare ..etc)  PoE is definitely my favorite Hack 'n Slash game together with the classic Diablo 2. It's a must try game for RPG fans and I would recomend it to all of you ;).

Long story short, this is one of the most engaging games I've played in many years. Path of Exile is a nearly perfect blend of intelligent complexity and mass destruction. It's probably not so intricate that a disinterested player wouldn't be able to find enjoyment, but it's certainly geared toward those who are inclined to plan, research, experiment, and occasionally fail in order to really flesh out their experience with the game.  And, as you've probably noticed, Path of Exile is completely free with no strings attached; the download is free, there's no subscription, expansions and patches are free (and frequent), and will remain so until the Earth burns up in a few billion years. The only things you can possibly buy with real money are almost exclusively cosmetic features, such as different visual effects for certain spells, visual affects for your character/gear, passive pets, etc. The only two non-cosmetic exceptions I can think of are increased and customizeable storage space in your 'stash' that's shared between characters (you start with four pages in the stash, which is not at all restrictive), and extra character slots (I don't even know how many character slots you start with, but I think I have eight characters and haven't yet seen the cap). If there were ever a situation where you get to 'vote with your money,' it's this. Ever bought a game and been disappointed but you already spent your cash? Ever wish you could have just played for hours on end without paying a dime just to see if the game is worth your time? This is part of what I love about Grinding Gear Games and their Path of Exile. Now that I've played a significant portion of the game I'm completely in love, and I'm fully justified in paying for some of the cosmetic features just so that I can help support the game and the dev team. I actually WANT to hand them my money at this point. And the best part is that I can pay however much I want, anything from $5 on up in exchange for microtransaction currency/coins, and even still get something extra for that money, like a mohawk made of spiked daggers or a crazy new look for my primary spell. Play for free, completely, forever, and if you do ever decide to give them some money you'll still be getting bonus stuff for a game you already love. It's simply amazing.  The passive skill tree can be a little daunting even after a serious investment in the game, but it also becomes rather intuitive and you just get a sense for how to operate within it. Grinding Gear Games' Path of Exile website has the complete interactive skill tree on it so that you can play around and experiment without having to risk your character to do so, though you will have to (really easily) copy-paste the link to a seperate website to get a list of how it all translates in terms of your hp, increased damage, resistances, and so on.  To describe the systems far more simply, and probably more boringly, than they deserve, Path of Exile essentially works like so, from my perspective.   1) Pick a class. Classes only differ in terms of their appearances, their starting stats, and where within the web of the passive skill tree they start, but not in terms of what abilities they can acquire or what parts of the skill tree they can reach.  2) Work the Skill Tree. This passive skill tree seems to be a pretty significant divergence from your standard fare where one would usually expect to be able to specialize by putting points into certain abilities; instead, as you level up you put your points into qualities and abilities that work in the background of your character. Most of these passives are individually fairly mundane, but many of them can single-handedly change the way your character will function.  3) Use your skills. Your abilities come in the form of specialty items that you can acquire through quests, random drops, or player trades, just like your equipment, and there are tons of them. Further, these ability items (gems) get placed on your armor essentially in sequences of your choosing such that they can have their effects altered.  4) Horde, and use, your currency. There's no gold in this game, which also means you won't find any gold farmers. The items that get used as currency are all things that you can actually use in the game to do stuff, not just a medium for transactions like gold would be. Each currency item does something different; among others, some of the currencies (orbs) can be used to upgrade a common item to a rare item, reroll the stats on a rare item, change the socket colors or socket links on an item, improve item quality, and so forth. These currencies are random drops as well as acquired by selling your gear or trading other currency items to NPC vendors, as well as by trading with players.  4) Rock your gear. The equipment is far more interesting than most any game I've played for two reasons. First, you can change any item in any way, though doing some of this can be quite difficult to achieve, such that you can take a perfectly common item and turn it into an amazing piece of equipment with your currency orbs; this significantly changes the standard 'farm until it drops' scenario that these types of games usually run into. Second, the ability gems have specific colors and they go into the same color sockets on armor such that blue gems go into blue sockets, green into green, and red into red (there are only three color types); the number, color, and connections between the sockets can do everything from simply allowing you to use multiple skills to significantly changing the way one or many skills operate. Equipment also has all the normal stuff you'd expect in a game like this, like various defensive or offensive stat bonuses, the occasional skill bonus, or whatever else. And, again, you get to alter all of the elements of your items, like taking a common item that has the sockets you want and upgrading it from a common item to a rare item, then if you don't like the random stats on your new rare item you can reroll the stats, or change the colors and orientations of the sockets, and so on. You're never, ever just stuck with whatever equipment happens to be dropping for you. Putting these qualities together makes for the least boring gearing system I've seen.  Now you roll all this stuff into one game and you get a really complex and compelling experience with a massive amount of customizability and replayability. Each aspect influences the others and there are absolutely no restricting ways to play your character. Spread yourself across the passive skill tree, then put abilities on your gear to compliment your spec; or find abilities you really want to use and then spec in the skill tree to augment or alter how they work. Define the type of character you're going to play ahead of time and restrict yourself to just those types of items, abilities, and passive skills; or flow through the game and define yourself as you go. There are definitely many specific paths that some people prefer, or some that are easier, or more defensive, or more offensive, pet based, supporting, etc., but you will find absolutely no shortage of wild and crazy speculative or even wildly divergent safe/noob-friendly specs on the forums or elsewhere online.  But all of these intricacies mean that you'll get the most out of Path of Exile by spending some time researching, whether it's scouring the forums or just watching some YouTube vids of people playing and explaining their particular character build. The more you learn, the more the game opens up and starts to seem even more and more exciting. I've put over 100 hours in at this point and, no matter how much I think I know, I search for something I'm uncertain about and find a whole new aspect of the game that I hadn't even considered yet. I see myself playing Path of Exile far into the future, and will support the game and the dev team with my money by choice, at my own

Aparently the game was made by the same team that made Diablo2 (which isnt the one that made Diablo3).  It really is D2's sucessor, the gameplay is pretty similar with the single big diference being the character customization. You can make literally anything you want, from a necromancer templar to a dual wielder dealing elemental damage.   Since i was such a big fan of D2 back in the day, i had to try this game. If you dont want to read all of it, skip to the end.  You have several classes to play, the one you pick basically sets where you start on the passive skill tree. At the end of chapter 3, you unlock the Scion class, which is the most versatile and can easy become whatever you want.  When you level up you get points you can use on the passive skill tree to make your character stronger. The passive skill tree is truly gigantic, hence the huge variety of choices when building your char.  You also get gems, that you slot into your items. Each gem has a skill, and the gems level up as you do. You can connect gems for extra effects, as there are many 'support' gems, that dont do anything for themselves but enhance other gems, with damage, skill duration, blinding enemies, extra effects like making melee single target skills splash for targets around, etc. There are 3 types of gems and gem slots, red, green, and blue, red being typically the 'brute' ones and therefore require strength, the greens require dexterity, and the blues inteligence. This gem system is very versatile, just like the passive skill tree.  The game currently has 4 chapters. While chapter 1 and 2 are kinda easy, chapter 3 gets harder, and final boss on chapter 4 is pretty damn hard.  So lets sum it up:  Pro's: -Easy to play. -Highly character customization. Want to shoot a cone of fireballs as wide as the screen, that also deal lighting and cold damage? Want to have an army of zombies, spirits and totems? Miss your whirlwhind D2 barbarian and want it back, but now dealing elemental damage? Yes please madam. -Free to play. -Areas change, so each time you replay each area the map is different.  Cons: -Visual perks like wings and stuff is paid, like guild chest, or extra chest tabs(but you start with 4 so that is hardly an issue). -Takes a while to learn and master the gem system, but once you get rolling you can make truly amazing things. -Gets kinda boring after a while. So just start another class lol.

Path of Legends is another great indie game to add to EA's records of acheivement. You start of with a selection from various characters, these include lulu the dark witch, taric the holy one, and lastly master yi the forgoten avanger. I myself played as yi and the story is great although it does have a few plot holes here and there. In any case you find yourself on a beach after the summer cruise ship you were on got assaulted by the deadswamp pirates. Yi was engaged to be married and had all of his family onboard the cruise at the time. unfortunately the pirates were ruthless and slayed every man woman and child. Yi tried to resist but was overpowerd by a surge of lightening on the stormy night that accompanied the deadswamp pirate assault. Amongst the wreckage of the ship he eventually floated to the island in which you start the game. Theres nothing much to it at first, you are lying face planted in the dirt. You learn to survive as you craft with various tools. Immersion breaks here because you cut down trees with your bare hands, but i suppose this could be attributed to Yi being a badass and so it can be justified.  Eventually you can build yourself a nice hut, and after you do some rather grindy farming you can establish a good forward outpost. You get promted mid game to purchase station cash from the soney online entertainment website to speed things up, but i never was a fan of DLC so i dont support EA's decision to monetise indie games like this. After you build the foward outpost you get to fight the first boss, a giant enemy crab which is symbolic of Yi's personal struggles from his japanese heritage. the crab is symbolic of real historical battles in ancient china and for the little historian in all of us i found this quite compelling as a plot twist. beating the crab allows you to advance to the next section, where you meet rico from just cause 2.   Rico gives you the grappleing hook as he too was on the cruise ship but took a bullet to the hip and just cant do what he did in the previous game. Fortunately for us, Yi gets to swing around the area pretty quickly. the hook allows you to make it to the central island, where the plot thickens once Yi discovers theres an american military base centred in the area that has been testing equipment. Yi appraoches the base in a freindly manner, but is instantly gunned down and escapes within an inch of his life. The game turns toward gurrilla warfare fromt his point on. You need to take out key military instillations over the island (such as propaganda stations and fuel depots) to try and win over the local populus. Once youve garnered enough strength you can take the military hq head on to liberate panaoa from the terrorist organisation that has rooted itself in the heart of the island.  THe final stages of the game involve strolling the halls of the HQ, which span deep underground. Yi uncovers the secrets this place holds. the organisation were responsible for the pirate attack on the ship, hired mercinaries trying to obtain a rare artifact being transported on the cruise that nobody knew about. This clearly explaines why rico was onboard and this was certainly no ordinary cruise. The artifact was being used to reanimate flesh to create necromongers to satisfy some weird cult called zoology established by Tom ultman. From this point on Yi knew what he had to do and where he needed to go... space... THe game ends with Yi having a choise to destroy the evil facility, or instead render it inert for future research by the alliance which hope to harness this power against the bretheren moons. Once you make your choice you can hitch a ride on the ebon normandy, a test vehicle in the hanger which is fully developed and primed for space flight. YOu can take with you some local aquaintances you met on the island, or just go solo. In any case, you leave the island and make your way to eden prime, and this is the basis for the second installment of league of exiles which we here at indieholic ardently await to get our greasy little hands on.  until next time, stay snazzy gamerz!

Basically this excellent game is a free to play Diablo 2 with a character improvement system that is QUITE REMINISCENT to the Sphere Grid from Final Fantasy X.   Except that the grid itself is... ridiculously big.  And if you are just playing casually, you can use it to develop your character in ways you want. But if you are fairly serious, you will need to find out ways to actually build effective and efficient characters, having entire trees planned beforehand.  And then you will need to get quite lucky or trade successfully, because skills are not bound to a character. That is both the game's greatest strength and greatest weakness, in my opinion. The skill system is INCREDIBLY flexible, being more similar to FF7's materia system than anything else.  Skills come in the form of 'virtue gems', which you get to slot into items with the appropriate colored slots. Said gems mostly come in rare, random drops.  You either need to trade for them (easier now since there are vendors that do sell some useful gems now), win many of them on quests, or trade with the community.  Extremely flexible, and if diablo 2 gameplay mixed with FF7 skill systems and FFX sphere grid character growth sounds interesting, you will probably devote many many hours in this title.  The ingame shop is only for cosmetic items, storage space and character slots, as far as I know, so there is no such thing as a pay to win scheme in this game.  EXTREMELY recommended.

It's been touted by some as what you actually wanted from Diablo 3. After playing it, I'm kind of inclined to agree. Active skills are attached to gems which you can socket/unsocket from gear at will, which can force decisions between skills and better stats when your new piece of gear doesn't have the right slots. There are passive skills awarded upon each level up that look a lot like the FFX sphere grid. It's possible to build almost any way you want using this, but each class has passive skills which you're meant to specialize in (i.e. are easier to access). Microtransactions exist, of course, but have no real impact on the game, unless you count extended stash space. Also, has perhaps the most unique health potion system I've seen which I'd like to see done elsewhere. Your potions have X charges and use a set amount of charges per use of the potion. These charges replenish as you kill enemies. Furthermore, these potions are stored in their own separate inventory.  Basically, if you're interested in this style of game and have the hard drive space, there's not much reason to not AT LEAST try it out. Afterall, if you don't like it, you're out nothing but your own time. Only complaint at the moment is that like Diablo 3, it is online only, which means the servers aren't local and it's possible to run into bits of lag here and there, even with fairly good internet speeds.

POE is like no other dungeon crawler I've ever played. The passive tree and skill gems are such unique character building mechanics that they became my favorite part of the game. The currency system has been excellently designed too; each unit of value is not only valuable because it is money but because currency itself is expendable for varying magical effects on your items, transportation etc. The graphics are beautiful and controls are easy to pick up/remappable. Some monsters, especially dungeon bosses can be very challenging (not to mention on higher difficulties - Cruel, Merciless) and take multiple tries to beat. The game lets you spawn back into the dungeon with damage you've already dealt persisting on the bosses so eventually you can brute force it if that's what you want to do, unless you are on Hardcore, in which case - Permadeath. Home building is mainly a neat distraction and hub for the Masters you can use to more easily craft powerful gear. My only complaint is that progressing through the whole life of a character to the end game requires that you do the same quest/storyline several times in a sort of new game plus style. The storyline is not bad by any means, in fact the world lore and theme is pretty cool but it can start to get repetitive. One of the best things about it, I've never spent a single dime and I get the same gameplay that anyone else who spends money on it does, because the majority of purchases available, other than more stash room (not necessary they give you plenty) are cosmetic only.  Highly highly recommend to anyone who enjoys dungeon crawlers, and to anyone who hasn't tried one before, why not give it a shot? Free-2-Play after all.

Might just be the best F2P game I've ever played. Looks gorgeous, sounds pleasantly, runs smoothly, feels very good to play. There is certainly a cathartic 'oomph' to the combat and the killing. Also, the F2P model is possibly the most honorable. The only items sold are cosmetics and stash storage space -- they're not cheap, but they don't impact the game.  There's a choice of 6 classes, which are presented to you much in the style of ol' Diablo 2: Templar, Shadow, Marauder, Ranger, Duelist and Witch. Unlike the old game, however, each class is very maleable and inter-changeable, in both passive skills and active abilities. The latter come in the form of gems, colour-code in regards to which attribute they adher to: green for Dexterity, red for Strength and blue for Intelligence. Each class has 2 initial direct paths of skills. A ranger, for instance, can choose to excel with bows, at range, or go the path of duel-wielding in melee combat. And at later stages, new, farther branches of passive skills are available to customize your character with, allowing you to mold your character's combat aptitude in detail. This might seem complex at first, but do not be drawn away, it's really quite simple and easy to map out. Lastly, I've noted nothing in the ways of bugs, glitches or significant imbalances.  Heartily reccommended to any Diablo player!

Backstabby guy with a twohanded sword? Check! Tank with minions? Check!), to the point that the devs encouraged the players to find overpowered builds. Path of Exile is a very deep ARPG with a rather unusual currency mechanic and a massive skill tree. It has a steep learning curve and can be somewhat punishing, but that's also what makes winning feel so rewarding.  The devs have kept their promise of making the game truly free. Most microtransactions confer cosmetic changes. The only microtransaction that actually affects gameplay is unlocking additional stash tabs (bank storage space). I found that when I only had one character, it was pretty easy to stay within the limits of the default 4 tabs. After a hundred hours of gameplay, I felt like a small payment to be able to hoard more items was more than justifiable (and a bit more to make my new character look super cool!).  The game is also kept interesting by regular challenge leagues where you start a new character in a separate game world with a fresh economy and different gameplay rules.   At a low low price of free, it's definitely worth a go!

Best action RPG out there right now, but not without its problems:  PoE requires too much dedication for hard working students and people with jobs or a family who want to maintain a healthy lifestyle. If you don't have a lot of time on your hands, you're better off playing some other game because you won't get much out of PoE.  The skill tree doesn't offer as much freedom as it first appears to. While the overall selection does greatly affect how your character works under the hood, they are still passive skills, most of which are just tiny percentage buffs and seriously underwhelming on their own.  I'm not a fan of D3, but the active skills in PoE do not satisfy like D3's do. There aren't any active skills that really make me want to build a PoE character.  In PoE you tend to build a character around one attack and spam that single one until you're blue in the face. Other action RPGs typically offer combined use of more active skills.  PoE is a thinking person's game, challenging, huge depth in its mechanics. It takes a long time and a lot of reading to learn how to create strong characters and it takes forever to get characters to a high level. The learning process is a joy, but respeccing isn't really doable.  The game changes a lot. If you leave the game and return after some months, you'll need to relearn wat makes a strong character, and all your character's passive skill trees will have been reset because the game's skill tree was likely updated. Your characters won't function until you reinvest those skillpoints. After returning to the game you likely won't know the current trade value of items.The game doesn't comfortably let you take a few months off and then come back.  They went too crazy with the socket colours and linked sockets. While fun at first, the impossibly low odds of getting the right sockets and links on your gear become an annoying limiting factor to how you build your character. Specifically, part of the problem is that the type of defence stat (armor, energy shield, or evasion) on a gear item determines what socket colour is most likely to show up on it. Active kills are gems that need to be socketed before you can use them, and they will only fit in sockets of the matching colour. This effectively forces you to focus on a specific defence type based on what active skills you want to use, severely restricting the endless freedom that the passive skill tree initially appears to provide.

Hardcore action rpg fans will love this game. If you're new to the action rpg scene(like i was), conquering this game may prove extremely difficult. The graphics are above average for a free to play game, providing a very dark world with creepy crawlers (lots of spiders) and catastrophobic caverns (lots of undead). The story is almost non existent with the game but it does try its best to add some lore. The game offers deep customisation in how you build your character, issuing one of the largest passive skill (yes passive) trees i have encountered in an action rpg (i have only played three). You can choose from 7 characters (1 is unlocked throughout the game), each differing in lore, sex and appearance. Path of exile lends it self to very deep builds and theorycrafting, which hardcore players will adore. Skills are collected from the world either from quests, drops or from trading with players. These skills are called 'skill gems' and begin as your fundamental action rpg spells. You will later acquire support gems which will provide unqiue abilites to the skill gems resulting in some nice effects adding to the games fluid combat. The game offers an in game store, however this is purely cosmetics based and storage space extensions which is initially huge anyway, offering no 'pay to win' bonuses. After a few run throughs (i did about three messing up all three characters after and before release) and starting a new character today, i felt the repetitive nature of the story and dungeons, and caverns overwhelm me. This is purely point subjective and will differ within the community. 11 hours of gameplay plus about 5-6hours during beta is nowhere near enough to fully enjoy and experience this game to its fullest. But i feel thats all this game will get out of me, which is a shame because i really do want to support the developers for their efforts. Path of exile is an above average free to play action rpg fans of the original diablo games will enjoy. Get your pens, papers, mathematics ready, this game's going to need it.

Whenever I was young, I used to drop thousands of hours into Diablo II.   Every waking moment of my life was spent grinding my way to max level on all characters, gathering immense amounts of loot, and playing around with friends for hours at a time. The game offered me massive amounts of reward, enjoyability, and replayability. So, naturally, when I heard that Blizzard was coming out with a new Diablo game, I thought my prayers had been answered. No more watered-down Triple-A games; this was it, my love of gaming was supposed to pool back into me with Diablo III.   Then I was disappointed - severely disappointed. Diablo III was nothing like the game I had played back in the day and I couldn't understand how Blizzard could screw up something so beautiful. With nothing left to turn to, I sauntered about the internet, searching for the ARPG that would take me away from the pain Blizzard had brought to myself. Torchlight was decent, but nothing too special. Drakensang was okay, but nothing to write home about.   Then I stumbled upon Path of Exile. I was hesitant, to be honest with you. The game looked solid from the screenshots, but I could never really know unless I downloaded it. Let me tell you, after 400 hours of this game, this is completely raising the standards for ARPGs and nothing (as of the date on this review) could ever come close to the quality of this game.      A massive skill tree, making for complete build diversity.     Overwhelmingly brilliant, lore-based atmospheres.     Visually stunning; what Diablo should have been.     Endless amounts of fun, especially with friends.     Developers that actually care! Amazing F2P business model.   I will forever be loyal to Path of Exile. This gave me my love of gaming back. This is what Diablo III should have been and wishes it was. If you're not sold yet, go ahead and download the game for a trial run. Every bit of content is free and there's nothing to lose. I guarantee you won't ever regret it.   Update for Atlas of Worlds   My review was done before the Atlas of Worlds expansion hit and I would like to reassure anyone wondering: yes, this expansion is amazing and, yes, the game is still just as good as it has always been.

Overview: Path of Exile This game is technically an MMO, but you will seldom encounter other players unless you choose to invite them to a squad with you. If it weren't for global chat, you may or may not realize that anyone else even owns the game while you're not in a major city. The gameplay is very dungeon-crawler(esque) with a good deal of lootfest and skill tree elements. Storyline: lol didn't read it, nobody has time for that (doubting anyone has time to read reviews either, but these devs deserve the time it took to give the review). Difficulty: initially there is only a normal difficulty, but a character can access a higher difficulty (cruel, the merciless) after beating the quest line on their current difficulty. Additionally, you can create normal or hardcore characters, the difference being that hardcore characters recieve better loot, but on death, they convert to standard characters, and all their gear becomes standard gear (and cannot be traded back to a hardcore character).  Pros:  1) Microtransactions aren't needed for late game.. in fact, there is nothing you can buy with money that results in an in-game advantage beyond a larger storage chest.  2) Character Balance and Variety. There are nearly infinite amounts of viable character builds and skills, not just 2-3 'use these or always lose' web builds for 'op classes' - from what I've seen, the classes are surprisingly well balanced. 3) Community. There are usually a lot of people chatting in global, and many people are willing to provide help either in-game or just give advice on items if you're inclined to ask. As always on the internet, there's a healthy amount of salt, and a few trolls, but such is the price we pay for gaming with other people. 4) Audio. The ambient sounds and the soundtracks for the game are both excellent, and the character attack sound effects manage to avoid being irritating although you end up hearing the same ones hundreds of times in the course of an hour. 5) Details. The devs clearly spent enough time in other games to understand what's annoying in an mmo, and they did their best to remove those elements. Most notably, potions don't clutter your inventory - instead, you can carry up to 5 potions, which refill as you slay enemies. The game doesn't have currency, instead players trade with chaos/fusing orbs, materials which can actually be used to upgrade items, rather than exclusively be used for buying and selling.  Cons: 1) Repetition. Although the creatures and attacks change, but essentially every level plays out the same. It's quite grind-heavy in that even if you progress through new areas as soon as you finish the quests, the actual gameplay remains redundant. 2) Actually.. being bored by the redundancy of combat is my only complaint. Although boredom is a death sentence in most games, I think I'll still keep playing this one... and even if you do quit if you become bored, there's easily 20 hours of early-game content which you'll probably complete before reaching that point.

If you loved Diablo II and haven't been satisfied with an aRPG since, this is the game for you. Now, I've enjoyed a few (wrote a review a couple of months back for Titan Quest which I still think is a great game), but this one is by far the most reminiscant of the greatest of them all.  Where this game surpasses all others is flexibility. With the enormous passive tree and the skill gem and linking system the possibilities are nearly endless. and these possibilities exist for each class.  Now I must also add, the one weakness of the game is also in its flexibility. It's entirely possible to build a character that will become useless past a certain difficulty. It can be very hard to get the correct gear in combination with skill gems that will fit in that gear. But these challenges just increase the reward when you get something that works, rather than guaranteeing you with a functional build from the get go by boxing you into a very specific path (a la Diablo 3... and no hate for D3 it's just an entirely different beast)  btw... this is FREE. So even if the good only sounds okay and the bad sounds really rough, it's still worth it.

This game is so ridiculously good. I started playing it in beta before it was on Steam after a friend introduced me to it, and the game has grown so much since then. It has so many unique things to offer. For those who want to know more...I will attempt to explain some of the things you will need to know from the start. It may sound daunting, but it isn't as difficult to pick up as it sounds.  A quick sidenote. Yes, it's free. No, it's not pay to win. There isn't a single thing in the store that gives an advantage over other players. It's filled with a ton of cosmetics, bank tabs, and character slots. None of which you will actually need, they're just nice to have.  For starters, there is the incredibly large passive skill tree with over 1300 passives on it. All 7 characters are positioned in different spots on this skill tree. The 'pure' characters are positioned on the passive skill tree directly within the three core attributes. The Marauder with strength, the Ranger with dexterity, and the Witch (my personal favorite) with intelligence. The 'hybrid' characters are the Duelist with strength/dexterity, the Templar with strength/intelligence, the Shadow with dexterity/intelligence, and the Scion (who isn't unlocked until later in the game) with strength/dexterity/intelligence. There are also jewels which can be socketed into the passive skill tree, that grant various buffs and abilities and sometimes alter other passives within a certain radius.  Next is your equipment. Weapons, armor, accessories, and flasks. There's a ton of possible stats you can get, and every weapon and armor piece will have a random amount of colored sockets on them, some linked together and some not (I will explain that more later as it ties in with your active skills). As for the flasks, you can have up to five equipped and those are what you use to replenish your health and mana. There's also some with a more niche purpose.  Your active skills come in the form of skill gems. These gems come in three colors: red, blue, and green. And what colors are those sockets on your weapons and armor? Red, blue, and green. You get skill gems as drops and quest rewards, and then socket them in the apropriately colored slot on your equipment. A piece of equipment can have anywhere from one to six sockets on it, depending on a number of factors. And if multiple sockets are linked together, then the gems in those sockets can work together. For example, you could have a skill gem that lets you raise a zombie, and then another one linked to that which makes your zombie do more damage.  The story is great, the soundtrack is cool, the NPCs are awesome. The game has full voice acting. Overall things have a really dark and gritty theme to it, and it's done very well. The enemies and bosses and even the areas get progressively more and more creepy. There's currently a total of four acts, each with their own unique things to offer.  There is so much more I could talk about, I've barely scratched the surface. The Forsaken Masters, corrupted areas, Divination cards, hideouts, leagues/events, the barter system (no actual currency in the game), all the items that can be used to alter your equipment, plus the special maps for endgame...but you can learn it for yourself when you play.

Path of Exile is a very interesting game. With heavy emphasis on mirroring a big portion of Diablo II's successes, Path of Exile presents itself as a serviceable and even downright appealing in a truly Free-to-Play game focusing on the idea of 'Ethical Microtransactions.'  As an action-RPG, it naturally gets compared to the likes of Diablo III, with a lot of players touting the oft-uttered 'This is what Diablo III should have been' among forumgoers. The comparison is hard to avoid since the game has similar mechanics but with a stronger emphasis on having choices with consequence.  Visually, the game's aesthetic is much more dark. In line with it's inspiration for gothic architecture and a lot of depressing atmospheres. Proper use of lighting to provide contrast in dark places in junction with lighting reduction as you're damaged really brings in the sense of dread when you are outnumbered and it becomes a matter of seconds before you die.  The game's soundtrack is absolutely stunning. They blend well with the environments without sounding far too similar to that of it's inspiration. Ambient audio also adds another line of what sounds like a full range of what belongs in each stage.  The passive skill tree is daunting at first, but once you manage to realize it's merely a presentation that can overwhelm you and that everything goes from point-to-point, it becomes fairly simple to figure out how to use it. Each class starts in a position and moves along the 'rails' one by one as they gain levels and skill points. Choices are fairly permanent, which is quite refreshing in an age where games continually make such decisions meaningless by offering people a chance to try again with no dedication.  Active skills could be compared to things like Final Fantasy VII's materia system. Each piece of gear will have a slot, which is color-coded for gem type. Green, Blue, Red, or elusive Whites. Some are support gems that enhance active abilities. Some are trigger gems, ones that cause an effect when triggered by play. All of which gain XP and level up when you use them.  Despite being a Free to Play game, Path of Exile manages to hold fairly fast to it's 'Ethical Microtransactions' platform which is to say that none of their purchasable items are to give any mechanical benefit. While people can argue that character slots (of which you start with 24) and stash tabs (of which you start with 4, and can be fine with) are a mechanical advantage, the game is very much 'Free to Play' in the literal sense. Gear drop rates are not based on cash spent. Drop quality is not based on cash spent. You can't buy better gear, and you can't buy experience potions.  So, Path of Exile has so far proven itself tremendously. It does a great job keeping itself reigned in, shying away from the easy-money route that other Free-to-Play games do, while providing an experience that even the bigger powerhouses in the market failed to provide.  Play this game. If you loved Diablo II, you'll be hard pressed to not enjoy this.

This is a complete head-scratcher. It's been around too long to not have a succesful business model, but I'm astonished at how ethical the microtransactions are in this F2P Diablo-alike.  No, no hyperbole, I'm truly astonished. I mean, it's almost hard to  find  the microtransactions, and they come in three flavors: Extra character slots, extra equipment tabs, and cosmetic appearances.  I don't know how many character slots PoE has, because playing one character is dozens of hours of playtime. Playing two (it's nice to have a 'solo' character and a 'co-op' character, which you can do without paying anything) is easily over 100 hours of playtime.  I still have enough stash tabs to organize my stuff into appropriate tabs. I might need more tabs some 200 hours into the game. Maybe?  And there's a huge amount of things to upgrade. Weapons and armor that has slots for skill gems, but also 'currency' items to buy items from vendors (no gold? Yes, no gold) that also affects your items. This helps the 'trash loot' and 'RNG gods' problems so much. If you find an item with great slots, but not enough else, you can enchant, disenchant, renchant, add more enchantments, craft on more enchantments, etc. If you find a great item with poor numbers of slots, you can reroll slot, reroll links, etc. How do you get these items in this Free-To-Play game, you ask?   ...from Grinding Gear Games, the answer is 'NOT by paying money. Ever.' You want those items, you find them or you trade for them. But wait, doesn't that create a third-party economy that might sell stuff out of channel? Maybe, but GGG resfuses to compromise the quality and feel of a game the depth of Diablo II to try and skim some profits.  The skill tree (web, really) is just bananas, too, in a great way. The selection of passive skills and abilities mixed with the equipment in this game encourages, again, Diablo II leves of creative character building, with a shocking amount of high-end viable oddball creations. (Just be aware of the vastly larger phase-space of useless characters you can make along the way, and assume you won't get your first character right. Really, it's okay).  The difficulty level make for a fun experience for those looking for a fun ARPG romp, but challenging theorycrafting challenges at the higher levels for hardcore players.  Best game I've played all year? Maybe. Most? Hands down.

Cons: -Inflation. There is no in game gold and currency takes its value by 2 means: 1. by practical value in crafting items and 2. by rarity. Some of the orbs can be obtained by vendor recipes and others only by loot drops. This leads to the loot-based ones to have sky-rocketed prices. Its like selling a 500 euro bill for 600 1 euro coins. You won't spend it and you will trade it. In my opinion, either all currency should have vendor recipes (practical value based economy) or none (rarity based economy). There have been some efforts to change this, like the Masters' crafting system and the Divination cards but that’s not enough. -Legacy items. When a Unique (legendary) item is considered OP they DON’T nerf it. They nerf the potentially future drops of the Unique item with lower stats. This leaves a finite number of 'officially OP' items for the richest individuals to play with. I just don’t understand the reason behind this. -Desynchronization. Hopefully this will change with patch 2.0. -Character movement is too stiff. -Lore integration in gameplay shines in its absence. Although you have a lot of decisions to make in order to advance a build , there is literally only one plot based decision to make (the Bandits). -Different items use the same art. At least the 2D artwork could be different.  Pros: -Great community (don't be overhyped trolls exist everywhere). -The build possibilities are limitless. -They nailed it with the atmosphere. -Oh Gosh I love the soundtrack.  Overall a great game and I recommend to everyone to check it out. Just remember to have fun, enjoy the story, try exotic builds…and I strongly recommend not to dive deep into the economy, it has flaws and chances are you will end up disappointed.

I am currently closing in on 200 hours, and feel better positioned to give a full review of this game.  The basics: Free to play, and everything people were actually hoping for out of Diablo 3.  The visuals: The visuals are what you would consider current gen for PC. Gone are the murky levels and textures of D3, and in with something clean and more modern. I've had no issues with slowdown, and GGG are continually tweaking the video options to ensure the game perform well across most PC configurations.  The sound: Decent quality, although you might run into some issues with Creative cards. This won't come as a surprise to you if you're had Creative cards forever, but it might annoy you until you find out what the issue is, and the work-around. Creative owners know that Creative updates their drivers once every two years or so, and tend to leave huge bugs unpatches. That aside, the overall game sounds and soundtrack are high quality.  What makes this game different: An insanely deep skill tree, randomized maps, and an unlockable character after you complete your first run. Oh, and it's F2P, and no Pay 2 Win from the micro-transaction store.  Difficulty Scaling: Three grades of difficuly, and end game content is well flushed out. Once you complete your highest difficutly run, you can loop back for items and things you might have missed, or you can start running the handful of 'Maps' that dropped for you once you got past level 60. These maps have unique challenges attached, and can have their quality adjusted to increase their rewards.  Grinding Gear Games runs new leagues in seasons, one normal and one hardcore, with hardcore death causing your character to be moved to the permanenent 'normal' mode. These are often referred to by trolls 'scrubcore' and 'hardcore'. I prefer to think of them as 'drunkcore' and 'coffeecore'. The microtransaction store they utilize to keep the game alive and in development offers only cosmetic items, along with the usual stash upgrades, and is relatively unobtrusive. They run special 'races' on a regular basis, which allow you to compete for Unique prizes each season. These include special dungeon runs, races to top level/area, and coming soon, PVP tourneys.  Overall, this is an incredibly solid and addicting game, and if you're a fan of ARPGs overall, you might find yourself logging quite a few hours in this one.

This is a very fun game. Definitely has a wide variety of abilities and character skill customizations: You can make a caster go melee with heavy armor and a two-handed axe, and visa versa. You are not limited to any set of skills, weapons, or armor sets. You have the ability to travel the passive tree in any way shape or form as you please. The GGG team always keeps it's players up to date with news and future plans for the game, so you are never left in the dark, and they release expansions and updates every few months. They continue come up with new ideas to make the game more fun. Of course, it is a free to play game and they rely on their microtransaction store for income, and you are NOT required to purchase said items. They also have supporter packs for those who are interested in helping them grow.   However, this game is not one where you can simply 'hop' in and instantly start getting unique loot. In Path of Exile, you have to learn as you go, so expect to delete many characters and try not to get too attached to them, unless you have come up with a build that you absolutely love. There are forums and other 3rd party websites that can help you come up with ideas on how to create a specific build. They also have a Wiki page to help out as well. You will start to find out by level 60-ish that your build will either suck or be really good. If your build does have an issue, looks like it's back to the drawing board and try to figure out what was wrong and how you can make it better. Also, the currency system is not like a normal MMORPG, so there is no gold, copper, or silver and etc. It has an material exchange system where you can trade a few of one type of item for another. They even have a 'Master' system, which is where you can help out any of the 8 masters that they have by doing small quests. And when you get that said master to a certain level, you will be able to get your very own hideout based around the master of choice and you can decorate it as you please by purchasing decorations from them as well. Not only that, but each one has their own crafting table, which, depending on which master, lets you upgrade a specific type of gear. At level 8, your masters will start selling unique weapons and armor to you at a reasonable price.  Do not to worry, as soon as you get the hang of things, the game is a blast. The story is fantastic and very dramatic. There are tons of unique characters that you come across and help. There are huge bosses that you can fight as well. This is a game that tests your knowledge and witts. Are you ready for such a task? Can you survive through all the trials and conquer the labyrinth? Are you strong enough to go against the odds? If so, take a dive into Path of Exile and show them what you are made of. Oh, and also, watch your resistances as they play a major part on whether you live or die.

This is what Diablo III should have been (at least in my opinion). It follows the tried and tested gameplay formula of this genre with an interesting character development system.  Skills are based on gems that are found throughout the game.These need to be socketed into items to be used and these level up with you as long as they are socketed. In theory any class can use any skill (although skill level is limited by the appropriate stat). In addition to this there is a large passive skill matrix which is similar in style to the skill development in Final Fantasy 10 (If any of you remember that one). For those who don't, all character classes start at different places on the matrix and (in theory) can access any skill, although some skills are much easier to reach for certain classes. This means that character development is much more freeform than it is in a lot of other games of this type.   I've only played three classes to level 20 or so so I don't know how the game holds up in the final stages, but it seems like an enjoyable, nicely put together game so far. It has PVP (which I haven't tried), regular events and (apparantly) a sizeable number of players. If you find yourself at a loose end one day and fancy taking a chance on an indie game, I'd recommend giving this one a try. Its free to play and as far as I can tell not pay to win, so what have you got to loose :)
