After having played path of exile for over 300 hours on many characters I have come to love this game. The depth of it's character and item customization is phenomenal. I find myself spending time outside of the game planning builds and discussing ideas with friends.  I started playing the game in softcore leagues. I was too afraid of dying and losing all of the work I had done in the league. After I became comfortable with the game and started to improve my skills I moved into hardcore leagues and haven't looked back. At the time of this review my current character is level 67 and just getting ready to move into doing maps.  Path of Exile's passive skill tree can be very daunting for a new player. It seems like you will never figure out what to do and feel overwhelmed. Many players use a guide on the forums from other players to learn how to play a certain build for a character and how to progress throughout the passive tree. Some people may say that having to look up how to play is bad but in my opinion it gets players to get more involved in the forums as well as into researching more about the game rather than just diving in and getting frustrated about not knowing what to do.  The economy of the game is kept balanced through the fact that the currencies commonly used for trading are also used by players to try and upgrade their items. This keeps the game from flooding with currency and having tons of inflation. Hardcore leagues tend to have a better economy since players dying takes items out of the league and puts it into standard. Causing the number of items that are good in standard to rise constantly, hurting it's economy some.  Even though Path of Exile has a limited number of classes and only 3 acts that are repeated multiple times per character and on every character, the passive tree, skill gem customization, and items cause people to want to keep playing the game and make new characters.  My advice to new players is to not give up too fast because you feel overwhelmed. Take a few minutes to browse the forums or watch videos to learn about a build or how to play the game well. If you put in the time to learn about the game you will be glad you did and enjoy the game.   There may be desync issues which can be frustrating but they are being worked on and they are not as bad as people make them out to be. You can easily play the game with those small issues and be fine.  I am willing to help out new players with the game or questions they have about the game. Feel free to add me on steam or in game using xHamsterHunter.

I have played this since 2011, and I cannot recommend it enough. If you liked Diablo 2 and other games like it, I don't think you will be dissapointed with this game, and since its free to play I don't see any reason why you shouldn't at least try it.   There is a permanent softcore league, permanent hardcore league. There is a 4 month softcore league, a 4 month hardcore league if you want ladder resets like in D2. And on top of that there are several race leagues daily if you want to compete on a very hardcore level.  You are very free in how you want to shape your character. The passive tree is gigantic and you can go anywhere you want on it. The only restriction to the class you choose is where you start on the passive tree. The builds are almost limitless, but if you want to do well in end-game you need to think about what you're doing.  This F2P game is actually F2P. There is no P2W or anything like that in this game. The shop consists of almost only cosmetic items. There is ONE thing in the shop that could 'help' you or at least make your time go a bit smoother, but again, it is not 'NEEDED' to play the game. The item I'm talking about is Stash tabs. Yes, you have an in-game stash much like in D2/D3. The stash consists of 4 tabs, but you can buy as many tabs as you want from the shop. So if you are a hoarder like me, you probably want to buy a lot of tabs.  The good thing though, is that the game is go good that I doubt you will think twice about buying some tabs and at the same time give them some support for making this awesome game. They are also expanding the game with content patches, new acts, new gems, items and what not on a regular basis.  Again, I can't recommend this game enough, I urge you to at least try the game out if you tend to like these kind of games. HF

Considerably enjoyable, to say the least. Building upon the skill tree action RPG (dice rolling behind the scenes) archetype set in stone by titles such as DIablo, Neverwinter Nights, Baulders Gate etc...The game does the time honored tradition well. The only concievable gripe would be the blistering lag and desynch issues and minor bugs. This is not so difficult with a reasonable internet connection.  The literature and surrounding world has been crafted excitingly, invoking much nostalgia of D2 classic and LOD Definitely doing an excellent job when it comes to the immersion into the world that has been created. Considering the amount of lore objects and voice acted bits you come across.  However many tricks pulled from the Diablo concept, this game is certainly a refreshing take. With no currency aside from crafting orbs, components, skill gems, and the subsequent support skill gems; any seasoned RPG nazi might find themselves completely immersed in building a series of characters.  The universal skill tree is sprawling, like dauntingly large at first. You seem to NEED to plan your toon ahead of time. Thankfully the stash is shared between characters on a server. So worst case scenario, breaking a character midgame isn't the end of the world. Merely running specific areas with enough rare item find capability allows you to administer a plethora of gear so as to build a new character.  Considering the recent introduction of the game, and couple of patches being released thus far; I imagine this title to go far.  Oh, and its free. Not like, work to level 20 before the game slows down and you need to buy your way to experience free *cough* SWTOR *cough* But free to play, not pay to win. Literally, you can enjoy the extent of the gaming experience without a dime going down the drain. Therefore, this is arguably the most enjoyable F2P title available. Thank you Steam/Valve/PC overlords for introducing this to me  (I still love Bioware and the Old Republic)  There is numerous series of 'season' events in which you register for a timed dungeon dive pitted in a race against other players. Each of these has specific parameters to set the environment and sometimes the difficulty for success. The most excitable (personally) is a hardcore open PVP ideal in whch other players may join your instance at will. Enabling you to butcher other individuals to further your chances at making it out on top, and helping yourself to their loot.  Based on your performance (levels gained, being the first to accomplish something(enter new area/complete quest) reaching certain levels marked in the parameters) you acquire points that accumulate towards a season total which allow you access to rewards (unique items that still have a percentage chance to drop in game) that appear in your stash.  All in all, worth the download. 7.5/10  But it's free, and what little issues exist can be rectified through further patching.......10/10

The last boss, Dominus, the man who has Exiled you to the slummed beaches is in no way a pushover. Those that have played Diablo in the past will feel right at home in this title. This is a game that shouldn't be overlooked and should be played. Path of Exile successfully captures the spirit of older action RPGs and updates it for an experience that's as visually appealing as it's fun. The combat itself doesn't differ much from other examples in the genre, but Path of Exile distinguishes itself with a unique ability system based on gems and a labyrinthine passive skill system that permits the creation of almost any type of character. Leaderboards, PvP options, and lootable challenge maps spice up the higher level content, and an unusual bartering system staves off inflation in its multiplayer aspects. Best of all, it's free almost to a fault, revealing a compelling alternative path for free-to-play projects to come.

Don't let my playtime in steam fool you. I have put well over 4,000 hours into this game and still play it regularly. I just wanted to write this review on steam so I could support the great game with another recommendation for people to play it. Don't let the complicated mechanics overwhelm you. Many of us feel that way when starting, but it's entirely possible to reverse engineer the mechanics and begin making your own builds. In fact, my most recent build was created entirely by me and is the strongest I've played so far.  If you are new, I recommend going on the forums and picking a build that seems like it would fit your playstyle. Once you get some items/currency/knowledge as a foundation, then you can begin experimenting with your own flavor of builds and playstyles. The more you do, the easier it becomes.  I also recommend the challenge/temporary leagues for new players because of the fresh economy. You will find better prices for gear there overall, and your characters/items/stash will all transfer to the permanent leagues when the temporary ones end. Eventually, you will understand how to start fresh in a new league with no items or characters, but you can still succeed.  TLDR: Play the game. Also, search the account 'reetismatic' on PoE forums to see how many characters I have made. My Prophecy league character is named Fair.

A sentiment shared by many is that Path of Exile is everything Diablo III was supposed to be. And then some. We all know how Diablo III turned out to be, so let's just leave it at that.  If you've ever played Diablo II in a serious fashion, you'll know what to expect from PoE. Throw in an incredibly large & open Passive Skill Tree and Seasonal Races with some seriously skilled competition, and you'll have entertainment for hundreds of hours to come.  By and far the greatest aspect in PoE is the freedom of choice. Want to be a Summoner Marauder using a 2h sword? You can do it and be damn good to boot. Want to play a Melee Witch with copious amounts of Evasion? Go right ahead. Only the sky and your imagination is the limit. Since every class can get, and use, every skill and passive talent in the game, you can do virtually anything you want to with varying degrees of success.  Skills come in the form of gems. You stuff your Skill Gems to your items along with various kinds of Support Gems for different types of secondary effects on your skills. Combine that boring old Fireball of yours with Greater Multiple Projectiles and Mana Leech to fire six Fireballs at the same time and leech your enemy's mana while doing so! Great fun!   But wait, there's more!  Unique items, or Legendary items, add in a whole new level of depth to your character creation. These items will give you solid +stat boosts, the effects of certain passive talents, or increase the level/damage/quality of your gems, auras, status effects or specific skills.  Or maybe you'd like a Bow which prevents your arrows from doing physical damage, instead turning that damage to lightning? Yeah, got that and many more.  Your choices, however, aren't limited only to skills, unique items and passive talents; you can choose from different League Modes: Normal, Hardcore, Domination and Nemesis. The first two are self-explanatory, the latter two are temporary ladders which last only a certain amount of time (half a year or so, after which you'll get different ladders), and have additional gear, monster affixes, permanent death, in-world items (such as shrines) etc. for increased variety, challenge and better economy.  Speaking of economy, the game doesn't have any set type of currency such as gold. You'll have to manually trade your items for different items with other people. No Auction Houses like Diablo III had or any such nonsense. Trading is brutal and if you're not familiar with the economy, you'll get cheated on and end up poor as a beggar. This is especially true for the hardcore D2JSP people with years of experience in D2 trading; they'll tear you limb-to-limb and you won't even realise it.  Patience and learning from your past mistakes is absolutely mandatory if you want to master the magical continent of Wraeclast. If you're used to playing RPGs on Easy or Medium difficulty, hate constant grinds for a few lousy pieces of gear, and loathe getting your ♥♥♥ handed to you on a plate: try another game.  Path of Exile is not for the faint of heart.

My most played game on steam even though I would reccommend the non-steam standalone client any day, due to some patching issues with the steam version. In any case, it just means this thing hasn't even been tracking all of my time spent enjoying this game.  It's years old, but still going strong and steadily expanding.  The developers keep making improvements to the game's content and the engine itself. Every 3 months there are new 3 month long 'leagues' which are separated from the permanent main game and offer everyone a fresh even start with a new economy which is an incredibly well working concept. Each league adds some new mechanics, skills or a twist on how the game works in general to always keep it fresh and fun and with unique challenges and rewards to boot. Additionally every 6 months (thereabout) we get a huge expansion to the game which is adding a lot of fresh new content to the game in often very unexpected and genre-innovating forms.  As a free to play game I have to say this: It is definitely the most 'free2play done right' game I can think of.  There are no cash borders on any content of the game, you can play and participate in absolutely everything and even the huge expansions are added for free to everyone. Everything in the cash store are optional outfits, visual effects or various non-combat companions (which serve no other function, but to look cool).  With the exception of one convenience item that is really only going to be needed if you want to spend a long time playing this game, in which case you really should throw at least a dollar at the devs! And that item is stash storage. Each player is given 4 big stashes for free, but if you want to hoard absolutely everything, you can do so buy purchasing more stash tabs. Every other week they also seem to run a sale on these so it's not even that bad if you wanted to purchase some. That said, you always have 4 free stash tabs for a new league as well and when the league ends they will move all these stashes and add them to your permanent game ones, so you won't ever lose anything and don't need to purchase extra space if you just want to store everything for eternity. Super generous and would basically allow you to play free forever and never lose anything.  I don't even want to get into the content too much because it's more fun to explore and engage yourself - there is an immense amount of knowledge to buildup if you want to understand and theorycraft everything that's going on in this. But for me - it is a literal THEORYCRAFTING HEAVEN. And I love every bit of it. Literally countless combinations of characters and ability combinations are possible. And this is really it's strongest point - mix and matching steadinly increasing amounts of skills and enjoying the outcome and seeing how far you can take it.  Due to having lots of different base skills (ranging from melee attacks, bow attacks, traps, remote attack summons or various necromantic activities) combined with lots of skill altering effects (such as increasing the amount of projectiles fired, forking them, adding explosions or various damage types, causing other skills to chain activate off of them , lots of unique items altering even more basic mechanic and skill effects AND SO ON.  Creativity knows no bounds in path of exile.  I know I'll be following this to the end and will enjoy every moment of it. And I hope somebody else reading this will too!

If you decide to take the plunge here are some words of advice to make the awful new player game experience less terrible for you:   1: A lot of people will tell you to wing it with the already imposing skill tree on your first character, those people are morons. Find a build on the PoE forums that says something like new player friendly or cheap, having some sense of direction is great, and getting to level 40 to find out you've bricked a character really isn't, it's frustrating as hell.   2: In some respects the devs are pretty dumb and irresponsible. Trade, which is essentially vital to the game is handled entirely through a third party site called poe.trade. Trade chat is a waste of your time 90% of time.   3: If you make it to like level 60, look up something called the chaos vendor recipe, it will take up a fair amount of your quite limited stash space, but it will fund your poe trade buys for cheap stuff, selling is a lot more of a pain without buying stash tabs but it is possible, if you make it this far it could be worth looking up.   4: Feel free to try something a bit weird once you've had a feel for the game. One of the reasons why I like PoE is that it's one of very very few games that let minion builds be really powerful. You know what's missing in these reviews? A 'not sure' button. That's what I need right now. I can't entirely recommend the game, but it's not a bad game either anyway, so I'm torn.  Things that I liked:  - Atmosphere and graphics are really nice. It's honestly the most atmospheric isometric RPG I've come across. The landscape is dark and brutal, the enemies more or less believable. From the looks to the sound, everything is pretty nice.  - Voice acting is pretty good, at times even superb.   Things I find controversial:  - The skill system is definitely interesting. Your gear has sockets that can be outfitted with gems. They come in different colors and can of course only be matched. Red generally is strength, blue is magic, green is dexterity and yellow I have not encountered any gems yet. This has advantages and disadvantages. For example my warrior can throw fireballs or send frosty shockwaves out (very handy at least in the early game, because enemies hit relatively hard). The more you use a skill the sooner you can upgrade it. Here's the issue however...I can no longer upgrade my frosty shockwave, because I lack the intellect to do so. Well, I'm a warrior. Chances are my intellect will not rise quickly enough to keep this skill relevant throughout the game. I'm not sure there's int on gear. AFIK you can 'skill' int, but that's also locked to very late in the game I think. Also, a rune usually only works with certain weapon types equipped, so if I find, say, a really good sword, but my mighty rune only works with a mace, then I'm out of luck. I then have to choose between the weapon and my skill (cleave for example). Frankly, this is annoying, and it's putting a lot of unnecessary thinking into the game imho. It also gives you flexibility, that's true, but levelling skills all over again must be frustrating...ever more so the higher your own level is.  - The combat system in general. It lacks 'oomph'. More often than not I'm not sure if my swings even connect or whatever, because in this game you can miss and you will miss and it's going to annoy you. Of course it's only fair that you can miss. All in all the combat feels a bit lackluster.  - It's free (to play). So far I can only see cosmetic stuff in the store like different pets and effects for weapons and so on.  - The story in general is 'ok'. You're exiled. Well, one would think you're just like the others, but of course once again, everyone relies on you for survival. It would have been nice if the other exiles at least fought for themselves. Once again you're the hero. You've just been exiled and you're struggling to survive, but please kill 100000 monsters, so we can relocate our settlement. Come on.  - There is no real economy in the game. Meaning you simply seem to be trading your gear for scrolls and stuff to identify gear and potentially buy other gear. It feels incredibly unrewarding, but of course it makes sense in the setting. What need is there for a currency when you're exiled to a dangerous island? Yet still it feels unrewarding not to collect gold. Not sure if this is the best system for an arpg.   Things I did not like:  - The minimap or overlay map is garbage imho. The color and visibility are lacking.  - The skill 'tree'. Basically you choose your class at the beginning, but that actually doesn't matter one bit (there's certain gear that you can't wear, because you lack the necessary stats) and that determines where in the incredibly huge skill tree you start off...sounds interesting? It isn't. At all. There are hundreds of skills to learn, but they are exclusively passive skills. The skill tree is excessively large, but largely boring. So far I have exclusively invested points into more strength and hps and some regeneration. That's it and that's what it's going to be for the rest of the game. What choice is there really? It's incredibly boring. Levelling up doesn't even excite me and I'm just level 6 or so, because I look at that tree and I think to myself...yay another stat point increase 0o. Wow. Maybe there are some interesting talents in there? I didn't find any and I looked around quite a bit...Why is it even in there? What customization does it offer? Everything in there is simply a stat increase.  - Always online. Yes, this is a multiplayer game, even if you don't want to play with others. You have to choose a server, pick a name, that is not taken, and jump into the world. Seriously. That's annoying. Granted you only see other players in PVP arenas and hub zones I think. I've not sunk enough time into the game to consider myself versed in all it's subtleties, but from what i've played, finishing the game once I can happily say it was an enjoyable experience. To adress the elephant in the room at the time of this review the microtransaction shop is not in any way gamebreaking, beeing fully there for cosmetic stuff and not game enhancing capabilities, unless you count a a shared guild stash.  DISCLAMER: Be ready for a long review and while i've tried to be objective there is no such thing my experience beeing coloured by games of the past. There's also a TL;DR down at the bottom of the review for those who want a synopsis.  To start off the review I have to draw a comparison to Diablo, the grandaddy of Hack n Slash RPG's.. This game mostly resembles Diablo 2 both in it's atmosphere and in it's approach to dungeon design, combat and loot drop. This can work both to the game's advantage and disadvantage, as most new players might prefer the breakneck pace of Diablo 3 combat, the straight forward loot progression and simplicity of level design in newer games. For me the only thing that could be improved upon, from the above would be the combat, adding some of the fluidity that comes with newer games. But enough with the similarities, here's what's different, and what might put off some people while drawing in some others: Leveling up in PoE will get you get a few points to spend in specific atributes, the difference comes in the form of skills and the passive skill tree.  Skills unlike in other games, are not inherent to your chosen class, they are found in the world through quests or loot drops in the form of gems. Gems have to be equipped in specific coloured sockets in the armor you are wearing, making the loot system that much deep and rewarding, but we'll get back to that a bit later.  Skills level up and gain XP, as your character, while you have them equipped. You have the option of leveling them up, to get a more powerful version of that skill, or not, for with great power... comes great manacost..! Skills can also be augmented and improved by other passive skill gems to add extra elemental damage, bounce, last longer etc.. whatever you can think of you can probably enhance, to the detriment of your mana cost. The passive skill tree is a giant web of intricate design, that min/max players will have a blast figuring out, while casual players might get a headache from, it allows to forge your character into specific roles, or enhance certain skills to act differently or become highly potent. The skill tree is shared between all classes, but the starting point in it is different; both a downside and an upside to this is that the skilltree will be familiar to players building new characters to try out different classes, and this also might bore some calling the game out for it's lack of diversity. Enough about the skills! Let's talk LOOT! ..or not? The loot in the game provides different values other than the highest number on the item. Everything in this game revolves around the skills and skillgems, the loot plays an integral part in it. A good item might be one with high stats and a couple gem sockets, a great item might have half the stats of the other one, be of common rarity and by having 6 gem sockets. Sockets and skillgems are of 3 different colours, red, green, blue. As you can imagine the socket and the gem must match, but what makes the system even more complex is the fact that you can improve a green skill with a blue and a red or whichever mix of the 3 you'd like or no mixing and just one color.  This is done by links between sockets in your item and possesing the right enhancement gems. As you can imagine your item might have 6 sockets, and none linked, or just 2 linked. You'd think but what are the odds of getting that kind of loot? Well there's a solution for that.. and no it's not microtransactions.

A complex Affixes/Suffixes system of item combinations makes it what people expected from Diablo 3: Being able to select what item I want to wear no matter is the primary stat of the class. Path of Exile also contains a HUGE Passive Node Skill Tree which contains somewhere around 1300 nodes which are accessible for each class because all classes use the same Passive Node Skill Tree. 100 levels, 3 difficulties, 3 acts (as for now), tons of mobs, vendor recipes and a different kind of currency that you will NOT find in other games. There is no gold in PoE, there are diversity of Orbs that have different value which a player discovers throughout the game. In resume: A game that is complex and worth playing. This is my absolute favorite ARPG to play. I loved Diablo 2. This game is a much more complex, hard, rewarding, exciting and unique Diablo 2 / Titan Quest ARPG. The RNG is real, the challanges are fun. The content doesn't get dull. Progression is limitless. Knowledge is never ending. Mechanics are so well done. The skills in this game are interesting. The ability to MAKE ANY BUILD you want is just simply the greatest.    My cons: Poor optimization, an SSD and good processor/video card/memory is required to play at a stable FPS.  The highest of tier content, maps, at certain point become very hard to aquire and sustain without a mapping group. It's doable but likely expensive for solo players. Not so much of a big deal if you really want to work towrds it.  There is still slight desynch in this game, but with the new Lockstep, the rubberbanding does not happen for the most part. The lag is very small when it does happen, it isn't gamebreaking unless you have a bad PC.  Overall, if you've never played an APRG like this before, it make come off as too hard. The hardest / least fun part of this game is first starting out and realizing you don't know what you're doing, and content is becoming harder and you have no idea what skills to use, what passives to take, what armor and weapons to use. What items to pick up to sell, what items are bad, what items are extremely rare. All of this stuff simply takes TIME to understand. I've played this game since closed beta, on and off. I learn somethng new all the time and people are still finding things out.  This game is good for casuals for the leagues that are never wiped. This game is good for semi-compeitive people who like to have fresh starts / new economy with new leagues. This game is SUPER competitive if you want to reach the top of the ladder or if you want to become a good racer. Racing is awhole nother part of the game that adds an interesting break from the typical game play.  The content updates are constant, the gaming company, Grinding Gear Games are simply the best of the best. On par with Valve and sorta kinda Blizzard-8-years-ago. There are bugs, there are issues, there is stuff that can be annoying or simply out dated (tetris inventory managment for example) but they are few and far and don't axe the game.  If you want to pick up this game and just mindlessly play-- you can. But you will reach a point in the game where you'll aboslutely need to gear properly and link your skill gems and get good flasks. This is always the biggest issue I see with new players. This is a game that rewards you for doing research, watching streams and videos and simply trail and error.  Don't expect this to play like an arcade game, similar to Diablo 3. It isn't noob friendly, but it isn't anti-noob. Make friends in this game, add people if you liked grouping with them, most people are friendly and are always welcoming to newplayers to help out.  If you're my friend, hit me up, I will do everything I can to make you realize this game. It's fun, I love it. Oh and it's 100% free to play. There is no pay to win. Extra stash tabs don't make you rich, knowing how to use them does. That said, they do give a big benefit to people who buy the, but there isn't a single person who cannot do what 100 stash player can compared to a f2p 4 stash tab. But it does make life easier.

Path of Exile is an awesome game. Let me cut to the chase and say it is exactly like Diablo 3 - it totally rips off Diablo 3, from some aspects of the GUI to the gameplay style. However, this is the best ripoff of Diablo 3 in the world. It's an awesome game, and I reccommend you play it. I was going to purchase Diablo 3, but Path of Exile fills my Diablo-style game needs. It's a truly awesome game, and the co-op makes it even better. I have some buddies that I play it with, and it's loads of fun.  However, comparing this to Diablo isn't that good of a review. Let me speak about how the game actually is. It's a hack and slash game where you collect loads of loot to make your character stronger. It's basically got the movement and camera angle of most MOBAs (top down, click to move your character), with MMO gameplay. It's not hard to get into, and it's satisfying and fun. Sure, you can grind, but in the early stages of the game, it's just pure fun - you don't feel like, 'Ugh, I have to grind FOREVER to get better armor because I'm too underpowered for this mission.' Sure, there may be some spots like that in the game, but the grinding is FUN! Just going around The Coast in the first act is fun in itself - you fight off endless hordes of the undead. So, if you have to grind, it's not boring grinding - it's fun.   For any MMO lovers (whether you like WoW, Diablo, etc.), I suggest you pick up this free-to-play game. If this game costed money, I would buy it. Now, if they slapped a price tag on it now in it's current state, I would not. They'd have to nerf the microtransactions, and make it a little more worth paying for. But, if they did a little more work on it and polished it enough to make people pay money (a one time fee, not a subscription model), then, yeah, I'd probably buy it.   I fully reccomend this game for anybody who wants something new to play either solo, or with their buddies. It can probably run on a potato if you lower the graphics settings all the way, so if your computer isn't exactly what you'd call powerful, this gem should run just fine and dandy. It only needs a 1.4GHz processor and an Nvidia GeForce 7800GT. I have a computer that's about ten years old that could probably run this game pretty nice at low-medium settings.   Okay, enough rambling. Short-and-sweet, DOWNLOAD IT! NOW!

Pros  +Free to Play but not P2W +Fun mechanics +Community +Alot of possible builds due to an ENORMOUS passive point tree +Alot of replay value +Creative active skill mechanics +Good idea of Economy in game +High quality graphics +Devs working with Community to improve the game  Cons  -DESYNC -Loading Screens take alot of time -Some areas like to lag the game a bit  Overall Opinion  Game is good, very good but not perfect. Path of Exile makes a lot of really clever changes to the ARPG/loot collection genre without losing what makes the genre addictive. Any piece of gear can be modified and changed into something useful by using common consumables you pick up, so you never really run into a loot 'dry spell' that prevents you from continuing onwards with the build you are trying to do. Skills granted by gems that are placed into sockets on items, so any 'character class' can use almost any skill as long as they have the stat requirements for it: if you want your rogue-like character to be able to use corpse explosion, he can. Skill gems can also be modified by support gems if you equip them to a piece of gear with connected sockets, so you can make your Corpse Explosion cause enemies to Flee or restore Health when you use it, etc..  Zones are highly randomized with layouts and monsters which keeps the game from getting stale each time you play it or start a new character. Lastly, the developers run timed 'leagues' frequently which encourage you to keep rolling new characters and trying new things to participate. PoE takes some huge steps forward for the genre, and is a far better game than other recent ARPGs like Diablo 3 or Torchlight 2. It's also free. What do you have to lose?

This is easily one of the most customizable aRPGs I've ever seen. Combat is like Diablo 3, but passive skills are done like the node map from FF10 and active skills are treated like materia in FF7. Combine this together and you can make any kind of character you want. The passive node map starts you out near skills that are typically desired for the character class you choose, but if you want to make a 2h sword wielding, minion summoning Shadow (aka rogue) you are more than capable of it.   Combat starts out slow, it takes a couple hours before you have the skills to do a lot, but when you do the game is incredibly enjoyable. Monsters are a nice mix, some of them being able to use the same skills you can find. The maps are randomly generated for the most part, with the maps generally resetting after about 8-15 minutes of you not being on it anymore.   There is no currency in the game. All trading, whether through NPCs or with other players is through a barter system. This makes trading interesting, with rarer stackable items being more highly prized as currency.   Music is nice and sets the feel of the game. There is voice acting, and it is very good, better than I've heard in quite a few AAA games actually.   Now the important part, the cash shop. This is a F2P game so obviously there is a cash shop of some kind... thankfully the developers did not make the game pay-to-win. The cash shop offers cosmetic changes and more tabs for your shared stash and that's it. No gear, nothing that changes gameplay, nothing that will effect how you actually play the game at all. You can change the visual effect of certain things/skills, apply skins to items you use, all just pretties that do nothing exept make you look fancy, as it should be.   The developers said in a review that they wanted to make a game that they would want to play, and it shows. Amazingly fun, incredibly customizable, and the first time you get get a rare, unique, or skill drop you are going to go 'squeeee!!!!'.

True sequel to Diablo 2 with little innovation in the core gameplay aspects of Diablo 2. Its basically a slightly different take at Diablo with the same core gameplay as Diablo 2, there is innovation; but it is in areas which needed it the most and are very outdated in Diablo 2 by now; those of simply put functionality - the simplest example is a shared stash among all your characters and you can buy more tabs on it, as many as you like more or less - this replaces the tiresome muling in D2 very well.  Community is relatively alive.  I am not a fan of the setting in general. There sort of are multiple settings, but they vary little. Act 1 is basically New Zealand; act 2 is kind of a wannabe jungle and A3 is ancient rome. Overall the atmosphere with its music and weather effects is rather bland compared to Diablo 2 which with its epic music and varying, epic settings and good weather effects was at times pretty awesome. Although I must say even Diablo 2 was not super atmospheric simply because it was an action ARPG, so it is understandable that atmosphere was not highly emphasized in PoE.  Overall gameplay is a bit boring. I wish there had been more innovation in the core gameplay as well. Though it will probably satisfy a diehard D2 fan.  After many many months of being well out of Beta, content variation such as monsters is still poor; it was much better in Diablo 2.  Theres also the issue of drop rarity. Many people who play alot have only found 5-10 Exalted orbs, while owning much much more in general wealth. It begs the question where do all the Exalts people have or use even come from? Finding exalts and such is therefore not satisfying even when it happens sadly because they arent even worth that much.  As far as I know there are no effective cheats such as dupes; I would consider this as part of innovation in functionality again.  There is great desync - and this is the real killer for me - I do not even imagine how hardcore players play. For softcore players death is also a big loss - exp is valuable, very valuable especially when you are doing maps - which is one of the late game activities in the game. There, exp is the main value of doing maps anyway, and when a part of the game thats not supposed to be there interferes and possibly makes you lose alot of the exp you have worked hard to get (trying to avoid death while kiling monsters) during doing nearly the whole map then this can be extremely frustrating. Desync adds an element to the game that you are not only fighting the monsters, but also the desync and this is tiring. Its not fun.  Character building and theorycrafting can be alot of fun and there are many, many options - more than in Diablo 2.  However, weaponry is limited - there are no javelins or spears, for example.  Overall I would not recommend this game unless you really love Diablo 2.

It's Diablo 2. It's literally Diablo 2. Oh my fudge.  This is a wonderful game. I just beat it on normal difficulty (and like D2 there are still Nightmare and Hell modes to go) which took me 18 hours for the 3 Acts the game offers. Unlike D2's skill / mastery tree PoE's active skills are all from gems slotted into your items. Your gems/skills level up as you gain XP with them slotted in. There's also a passive skill tree that is like D2's tree (actually, it reminds me of FFX's sphere grid mostly). The system works pretty well in my opinion thanks to the customization offered by support gems (skill gems that modify other skill gems) and you find yourself considering whether an item is worth swapping for another item given the number of slots, links, and colour of the slots. There's a lot of nuance and different builds and optimization to look after. It's the same wonderful time-sink that Diablo 2 was.  The most notable downside is that I've seen some desyncing problems. Occasionally a mob will aggro on me, I'll hit it but not actually do damage and then a few seconds later the mob will teleport to its actual position. I've also had some problems where I'm running through a group of mobs and run past them, but the server-side code decides I actually got hit and stunned and teleports me back to the middle of the group. This happens quite a bit actually and is very noticeable.  Overall a fun game. Even if you aren't going to sink your life into this Diablo 2 work-alike you'll get ~20 hours of enjoyable gameplay for the low, low cost of free.

Kiss your life goodbye.   PoE is an ARPG akin to Diablo, with extremely rich character customization options. You acquire skills via gems that function identically to the Materia system in Final Fantasy 7. You equip gems to enable skills, and can equip support gems to modify those skills to your liking. The combinations are endless.  Character development is done through a gigantic passive skill tree that can be a bit overwhelming at first. Your first couple tries might not be very good, but once you understand the game and what you need it will be much easier to use. It greatly resembles the Sphere Grid of Final Fantasy 10.   The game can be played in Single Player virtually the whole time, but multi-player is preferable at later levels. Trading is a necessary part of the game later on, however it is very clunky and sometimes quite painful.   By far the best aspect of the game is that it is NOT pay to win, you can purchase convenient upgrades for your inventory or aesthetic effects, but by no means will putting money in help you advance through the world. The game increases in diffculty greatly in the 3rd difficulty level and will challenge even the msot experienced players of ARPGs.   There is a story but it's not really required to understand the game, I've never bothered to look into it. Quests are abundant, although rewards could be a bit better at times.   It's free, almost to a fault. This is a game you SHOULD pay $40 for. 200+ hours and 4 different builds later and I'm still enjoying the experience.   8/10: The trade interface (or lack thereof) and other minor quality of life features that are missing keep this score from being higher, but the core experience is absolutely delightful.

Before I started playing Path of Exile, I had some expectations. These expectations only came from the amount of hype generated by people who played it and complimented it as the best of the genre. It's true that the game is 100% free to play. You can go from beginning to end in all difficulty levels without spending one cent. The developers stood by their words and have guaranteed a completely free to play gaming experience. The best selling micro-transactions are either more stash slots or cosmetics. Everything else can be acquired in-game and for free.  The setting and theme are done well, borrowing from both fantasy and horror alike and providing an interesting enough mixture of the two in the game world, enemies, classes, items, weapons, and spells. The voice acting is good, and the ambient sounds, music, and sound effects are also all of good quality. The gameplay is what you can come to expect from a very standard action RPG, with the only innovation being in the form of spells and how their mechanic is employed. People seem to often be in awe of the passive skill tree, but it really is very straightforward and not too different from other similar games. Possible class builds and paths have something for everyone's play style.  Loot is one of the main focuses of the game, and this is also a big disappointment for me. The loot in Path of Exile is simply not very good. There is very little variety between what you find and what is actually useful. There just doesn't seem to be enough loot for a game of this scope, where multiple playthroughs are almost expected for the sake of it's longevity. I personally can't imagine what someone would find enjoyable and redeeming in a second, third, or more playthroughs of Path of Exile. There just isn't enough variety in anything. The loot is not interesting at all, sadly.  My favorite aspect of Path of Exile is the naming of items and enemies. The developers did a great job in coming up with many of those titles. This game has a lot of interesting things going for it, but also a lot of problems too.  First, while it hypothetically has 'millions of combinations' like most games with this sort of customization, there's 'what you can do' and 'what actually works' which is usually 5-10 specific builds built to just clear endgame over and over.   The game is somewhat interesting, interesting world, interesting lore (if you can be bothered to read it in the hundreds of times you'll see the same lines over and over).   As a FTP diablo clone, it's not horrible, but very quickly you realize that optimal clear speed is the only thing that actually matters in the game, unless you're trying to farm 1 specific endgame boss (which there are not many of). There are 'tons of unique items' but probably 80% of them are just jung to toss away the moment you get.  Even leveling is incredibly boring, similar to Borderlands, you just play through story mode 3x, then get to endgame content, except 90% of endgame is just grinding more, and there's much less story to enjoy, even if you don't have to listen to claptrap.  It also doesn't help the game runs like crap on every computer/system I try it on, my computer is capable of running VR flawlessly, and still many zones in POE only run at 20-30fps. I've been trying for a few months to fix it with no success.  There are some cool things here, like the breach league 'open portals where enemies can stream in' except all this does is provide a condensed meat grinder to reinforce the clear speed meta. It wouldn't be so bad if you needed a different strategy to clear bosses, but 99% of the aoe skills in the game are stronger than the single target/melee counterparts, so there's honestly almost no purpose at all to not go aoe clear. And once you realize that, you realize that 'if i'm going to go aoe clear, i might as well just build the most efficient one' which is pretty much the same as everyone else.   There's the atlas... which was kind of cool, except the supposed '100 unique maps' are more like 30-40 with many assets and even whole areas completely re used and called something different. all this does is make the endgame grind more annoying as you just have to hope to rng that you get a better map so you can get closer to the bosses of the maps.   i could go on... for a long time. In my opinion, this game has a lot of cool ideas, but has implemented most of them very poorly.   If you like diablo and just want a F2P game that's kinda the same, but much harder, give POE a try, but I don't recommend sinking as much time into it as other games.

+ lots of skills available + lots of builds possible ++ great graphics ++ free-to-play without any pay2win features at all + good replayability  o Many of the skills in this game are very similar to each other, only being different regarding the type of elemental damage or the type of minion, etc. I feel like the skills in Diablo 2 were more original - they suffered from balance issues of course but that is another topic... o Gritty graphics but total lack of atmosphere. Music is alright but somehow the atmosphere does not really come up at most places. A lot of places feel the same and very generic. Others are really well made, but those are the minority. Too much repetition in enemies (some are just coloured differently and given a new name..)  -- desynchronisation issues make the game feel 'detached', what you see on your screen does not correspond to what happens in the gameplay and other issues arise such as sudden teleports leading to deaths etc. This issue has been around since beta and has only gotten worse since then. EDIT: They added lockstep now which shows you what actually happens on the server, but the lag spikes are so bad it is unplayable with the current servers. My broadband internet connection with no packet loss and steadily low ping is definitely not at fault at this... - the passive skill tree is huge but somewhat meaningless: In the end you only go for the important nodes for your build anyways, and mistakes are costy (lots of currency orbs needed). also this concept is barely balancable and optimal skill tree builds take a lot of time to plan. If you enjoy this planning (I actually do) then this is somewhat fun but in the end the concept feels a bit pointless and when you go for certain skills there is usually not much choice if you want an optimal build. This means that there is actually not as much freedom in skilling as it may look. For certain builds you will always target the big nodes necessary for it and you will have to take all nodes on the way to there - not really exciting. The rest is just optimisation and alteration, not making much difference usually. -- We were promised new acts. The game got different kinds of new content, but there doesn't seem to be much development regarding new acts, although this is exactly what this game needs: more acts, more NPCs, more quests, more story-related content. - The skill effects and particle effects in this game are too large, obfuscating and opaque. Often it is impossible to see what is going on especially when playing in larger groups. There is no way to lower the visibility of those effects or turn them off. It kinda ruins the game in a way, but I guess some kids might like it... -- The whole game seems to be developed more towards grandstand-play and more and more customised effects, random grinding and 'loremasters' (who the heck needs that) than towards new content, balance, compelling gameplay, and fun that is less grind-related (a bot can do that..). I don't like the direction it is taking.  - Currently the only way to play this game in late-game is to have some form of AOE and/or abuse game mechanics and imbalances. AOE is necessary because desync becomes ridiculous in late game, so ridiculous you barely can play if you depend on direct hits, even if your ping is around 30 ms. Fixing desync would fix this too.   Summary: Could have been a great spiritual succ

At it's core , Path of exile is a good game. It contains all of the qualities people look for in this type of rpg. That being said, it is an exercise in frustration if you do not follow it's spacific formula for success.   The most glaring problem with the game is its poor net code. You will die to desync in this game. You must train yourself to constantly be on guard for the signs that your character is not synced and try your best to mitigate it's effects. This makes hardcore leagues and races tedious and saps the fun from them. No other game of this type, or any type for that matter has ever been this bad for me. The devs are aware of this problem, but have been unable to make any progress toward a fix.   If you decide to play softcore, or get sent there from hardcore, you will deal with experience loss on death. The devs are fully aware that desync exists, they can not fix it, yet they leave a punishment mechanic in game if you die, when they can not differentiate between a deserved death, and one caused by thier poor engine. At higher levels this can mean hours of grinding wiped clean through no fault of your own.   There is no pay to win mechanic in this game. You must earn everything you need to progress through gameplay. The drop rates are well tuned, but the chance of getting anything you can actually use are so low, that you are forced to trade in order to progress once you get to the end game. This is true for a lot of games, but the problem here is you have to either watch tradechat, or use third party sites to obtain the gear that does not drop for you normally. This is time consuming and tedious.   The learning curve in this game is pretty big. There are literally millions of builds that you can end up with as you traverse through the game, but many of those builds will not be viable as you close on the endgame. The most basic rule you must follow if you want to succeed in this game is, Research, Research, Research. If you just start the game , and do not do research, it is very likely you will end up at a progression wall you can not climb. In most other games, this is not an issue, as you can take the lessons you learned, buy a respec token or whatever and fix the problems with your build. This is not the case in this game. Respecing is expensive, (in game money, you can not buy a respec for real money) So you learn that you are better off just shelving your character and starting over from scratch. with no variation in the game story, it becomes just a borefest to get back to where you were previously with your new build.   This game would get an enthusiastic Thumbs up from me if it were not for the above issues. As it stands now, I would suggest to anyone reading this to research what desync is if they do not know, and see if they have the ability to mitigate it enough for the game to be enjoyable. If you decide you can live with it, I suggest you do some deep research on the skill tree and game mechanics, before you even start playing. You can find a lot of cookie cutter builds on the forums if you do not want to theorycraft yourself.   If it were not for the desync/death punishment mechanic I would endorse this game to anyone who loved Diablo 2. Instead I will have to vote thumbs down on this, as the issues I listed will not be fixed, and just cause too much frustration as you close in on your end game goals.

BLUF: There's no reason NOT to try this game. I, however, don't think the game is fun nor worth playing; it has copied many of the most frustrating parts of other action RPGs. Not only does the game not teach you it's numerical systems (or even have a how-to-play level), but many important numerical systems are hidden, and in higher dificulties you are penalized for not understanding every single skill and aspect of the game intimately.  Path of Exile is a true F2P style game without Pay to Win systems, which is admirable, and several systems which are quite interesting academically. Sadly the overall lack of pollish, poor ballance, realism art system choice, and camera issues [too zoomed in], and extreme changes in difficulty hamper the game from actualy being fun.  There is a very vocal die-hard fanbase for this game who all tend to cry wolf all over it, raising it above games like Diablo 3. Do not read forums for this game, they are terribly misleading. The game has some interesting systems that gave promise, but it's completely without polish, and requires HOURS of research to understand the innards of a 'good build.' I do hate to use epithets , but 'you tend to get what you pay for' actally fits here. The game is playable, but also instantly forgettable. In several areas you'll encounter sharp encounter difficulty spikes which detract severly from immersion.   The realism art style is unfortunate because it hampers your ability to see, fight, and play quite often in dark places like caves and dungeons. It's blandly done realism art is over-dark in many areas, unimaginative, ugly, terribly repetitive, and detracts by distracting you from being able to easily see enemies far too often. By the second playthrough you'll find the gem-based skill system is plagued by ballancing issues, and the stat-map ends up being annoying, frustrating, and forcing re-rolling more often than offering real freedom of character choice.  Overall, the game is not as fun as dungeon crawl games that have been released before it, or even as good as Diablo 2 on which it's obviously based. I really really wanted to like this game, as several of my real life friends enjoy it. Sadly it's certainly no where near better than any of the games people claim that it is.

But as I moved into the higher difficulties I found it becoming more and more of an issue, until eventually I reached a point where I was 'stuck', my progress had slowed to a glacial crawl and would stay that way until I got some better gear.  So I grinded... and grinded... and grinded... and grinded... and after about a week of grinding and looking at various trade sites/channels I had 1 upgrade. By this point I was just like 'F*ck it, I don't care anymore' and gave up. And that's the summary: Poor Itemisation/RNG that brings down a very good everything else.  Still, it's F2P and not that large, so it's still probably worth at least a try. Who knows, maybe you'll be luckier than me!

Very good hack'n'slash game with a complex skill system. One of the bests I've played so far. Which I really like is the gameplay mechanics. You get attributes and passive skills from a really huge skill tree, which shared by all classes. You obtain active skills from skill gems, which can be inserted into item slots. The basic currency is the identify scoll, which is really unique in my opinion. It is a multi-mmo-coop like game, you can form parties with other players or play pvp. There are different kind of leagues to choose from, which affects the gameplay and gives it a replay value. (hardcore, ambush, invasion, open pvp etc.) The world, the lore, the controls and the action are well done, the gameplay is very addictive.  It is free-to-play, but you don't have to use the item shop to enjoy the game. (it only offers cosmetic enhancements, which is really fair) If you liked Diablo 3, you should definitely check this game out. It is much more than just a D3 clone.

It was fun at first. Similar to D2 with better 3D graphics.  Positives: - Free to play - Interesting skill tree with lots of possibilities, mixing and matching from various skill sets. Class type only defines your starting position within the tree, but you are free to move about it as you see fit, collecting the skills you want. It has great potential.  Negatives: - The servers (must play online) are very out of whack and all too often the mobs are not where you think they are. In effect you are fireing at an on screen ghost, or there is nothing around you yet you are still getting hit with damage. - Loot drops are terrible. The seem ok in the beginging, but there is no real progressing in quality related to player level. So it gets tiring. - The crafting system pretty much makes all loot virtually the same almost worthless value for NPC trading. So you must go to the player market. Which in itself is very tedious. - At higher levels the skill tree and playing skill becomes marginalized in relation to specialized 'must have' equipment. This destroys the self-found playing style. - The skilll tree has a major hic-up in that at best you can have only 120 nodes. This limts the real varity in character types that are playable...Most are cookie cutter around specific equipment. And it gets boring after a while as you really learn how the tree works. - There are various severe balance issues regarding combat (especially Act 3 endgame). - The casual single player is screwed, as the game design is geared toward devoted hard-core multy-player groups.  In a nut shell, unless you are all into intense socialization in order to get equipment to win, you will likely not find this game keeping your interest.

Hmmm, how to sum up path of exile.... Aesthetically it's dark and gritty akin to Diablo 2 It's gameplay is much reminiscent of Diablo 2 as well. left click move, loads of loot, the tetris invintory, loads of loot, and the grindy gameplay with loads of loot.  Skills ingame are more influenced by FF7' materia system on crack, levels give you passive skill points which you use to increase base stats like move speed or bow damage, and then you reach a keystone passive such as Minion Instability (minions become nukes upon death) or Eldritch Battery (mana shield becomes mana pool) or even Blood magic (give up mana pool use hp as mana) and now you have gameplay changers.  Skills are gems dropped as loot. you equip them into their respective colored sockets in gear to use them and bind them to your keys, and sockets can be fused, allowing them to be upgraded by skill gems such as multiple projectiles, chain, fork etc; and then you get: Lighting Arrow (skill)+ (support gems:) greater multipl projectiles+chain+mana leech+elemental proliferation= now you get5 shotlightning bomb arrow that chains from hits and auto targets nuking a room  IMO the skill system allows for endless possibilites on making custom skills as they ad more and more active AND passive skills every update.  Tack on randomly generated item stats with a huge database of combinations, and you get crazy and interesting items. And the legendaries ingame ACTUALLY change gameplay style at times or even builds. Kaoms Heart (legacy) for example, you forfeit your body sockets (VERY important because you give up a possible 6 linked godly skill) for + 1k hp which turns you into a tank and is crucial in a few builds that involve blood magic.  tl;dr Diablo 2.5; if you like Diablo 2, 3, or even Torchlight 1/2 you'll most likely like it once you get used to it's game mechanics

I've had this game for awhile now. One of the first I picked up when I built a new PC for myself after many years without one. As of today, I have officially punched in 200 hours across 4 characters, and my love for this game is still growing.  To describe it as anything other than Diablo II with the gem system very much identical to that of Final Fantasy VII would be an insult to all parties involved. The game has a very beautiful, dynamic way of producing combat that makes you feel very rewarded when you cleverly link together a few spells and modifiers and, as they say down south, 'bring out the ♥♥♥♥ train.' The passive tree is massive, and albeit it a bit daunting at first, makes sense and while being balanced, still offers many many ways to play every class, no matter what skills you pick to rely on.  Of course it doesn't come without its list of gripes. The chat system is clunky and often annoying when trying to switch between channels, wispers, and party talk. Also, since the game is server based, the amount of 'desync' can get super frustrating. Often times you'll try killing the same enemy over and over only to have it warp across the screen as the game 'syncs' or something flinging you FIRST INTO A MOB OF MONSTERS. Did I mention you lose XP when you die? Yeah.  But that just adds to the difficulty of the game. Following in the same vein of games like Dark Souls where certain things are designed in such a way that you must do them in the most difficult manner possible, it's a real test of patience. Casual gamers might enjoy it being that it's free, but if you want to work your way to success, be prepared to devote a lot of time working through tedious item crafting and farming. If that's your kind of thing, then you'll definitely feel at home with the no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t crafting system in this, where all of your rolls are completely random and you can often find yourself RUINING gear instead of improving it. A life lesson to be found in that somewhere, but I haven't yet.  All in all, an incredibly rewarding and cleverly designed game with layers and layers of character creation and manipulation that most ARPG's just seem to lack anymore (Yeah I'm talking to you Diablo III). PVP might be a little nonexistent (which is a shame because this game supports 1v1, 3v3, and 6v6, both conventional arena and Capture The Flag). A solid 8/10, and highly, highly reccomended.

So incredibly good. If you're looking for an ARPG, this is the one. It has more depth to its systems than you can wrap your head around in the first 100 hours of play, and the gameplay is so much fun that those 100 hours will go by before you know what happened. The temporary leagues keep things fresh with special new rules in each one and a fresh economy where everyone starts from scratch.   On top of how much fun the game is, the developers are just the best in the biz. They engage with their community to a degree I've never seen another developer achieve. They listen, and the passion they pour into their creation is plain to see. The game is constantly evolving and improving. The upcoming Awakening Expansion, branded version 2.0, contains TONS of awesome updates, new content, and quality of life features. Feeling like you are part of an evolving creation really adds to the experience.   The game is also truly free, and uses the most ethical f2p model I've seen. Pay-2-look-fabulous is what the community calls it. Purchases only change your appearance. There are no XP-boosters or OP weapons or anything of that sort. The only thing that has a direct impact on the game is buying stash tabs, but you get plenty of space by default and extra is only a convenience. Some people pour money into this game, but nobody has to. The people who do are absolutely in love with the game, and the devs deserve every penny.  This is a desert-island game. If you were stranded with nothing but a PC and an internet connection, you could be happy playing PoE for the foreseeable future.   There is a steep learning curve in the beginning, but as long as you learn as you go instead of trying to figure out everything at once, you'll start to see the brilliance of this game. Watch some streamers, check out the Reddit, and you'll get the hang of it in no time.  10/10 Best ARPG of all time.

You know the deal. Another Diablo rehash of isometric graphics, tiny packed inventory, some stuff about darkness and more common quality loot than you'd ever hope to see. The graphics are on par with Diablo 2 and it's gameplay is just like every other of these games; it doesn't even try to advertise around these things, so you might ask: why Path of Exile?  Because unlike most Hack & Slash games, Path of Exile is giving the player a lot of freedom of choice in how they want to play. Sure you've got your basic pack of heroes to choose from from the start, but the only thing your class sets in stone is /where/ you start off in the passive skill tree. And active skills? They're available to all classes as well, because they're introduced as socketable gems for your gear.  You're not bound to a little list of talents and skills and passive; ten levels just to upgrade one passive skill increase cold damage? Not in Path of Exile - every passive skill you take basically leads up to more interesting paths of passive skills, every level presents a choice.  And unlike most Hack & Slash games, there's constant progression. There's still the same feeling of grinding randomized areas, but in Path of Exile, every grind you do can give you the currencies or skills that are just as useful at the maximum level. Even common gear can be valueable, and every currency has it's role (there's no gold or copper; currency in Path of Exile are basically tokens that can upgrade or alter gear useful at all levels!). Meanwhile, your socketed skills level up with you.  Path of Exile is more than just a grind to the maximum level and then farming that end boss for that one chest plate you really need. It has constant leagues to introduce a new challenge for remade characters and every single piece of gear and every single skill can be modified, altered and changed to suit your playstyle.  And last but not least, even if this really isn't in your alley and you'd rather go back to the wrist-straining, mind-numbing other Hack & Slashes, you wouldn't have wasted a dime, because Path of Exile is free to play!

This game is everything a hack and slash should be. Brilliant yet complex character customization. The skill tree is overwhelming at first, but with patience it makes perfect sense. You can build your entire character around one ability and turn into a one shot monster. Or build to support a few specific skills, and make an excellent support class. With the ability to customize any class into almost anything, there is more options for collecting gear, and skills, instead of vendoring or trading everything. The atmosphere of the game is a great homage to the classics. The sound track and environment sounds are excellent and pull you right into the experience. The voice acting is top end. The server de-sync issues are annoying, but not enough to destroy the game as of yet. The ethical micro-transactions make this game a true Free-to-play. One which clearly people support, as I will do in the near future when I can afford spending on a support package. For everyone that loved Diablo 2, loves Diablo 3, and is tired of the cookie cutter character builds, limited skills and perks, this game will allow you to creatively pursue a character build not seen anywhere else.

Randomly generated levels means it's never quite the same twice, and there's great art variation between areas. Let's get things out of the way first and foremost - Path of Exile is the true spiritual successor to Diablo 2, while Diablo 3 caters to a completely different play style and niche. Both are good games, but PoE is what D3 should've been.  With that out of the way, let's start with what PoE is. It's... an action-RPG dungeon crawler from a top-down isometic perspective. Or, in short, a Diablo clone. Which's not really a ringing endorsement in itself, but rather than it does everything the genre has set out to do but better.  There have been issues within the genre since it began. Mechanics which never quite worked right, which people have been attempting to solve for ages. For example, Diablo 3 introduced health globes where enemies tend to drop healing items at the end of a fight which you can pick up to restore your health so you can move onto the next fight quickly without slowing down. The 'danger' in combat should be centered upon the idea of running dry mid-boss fight, or during a single swarm of enemies, not being worn down gradually over time and being forced to head back to down, not even to drop off loot, but just to replace potions.  Path of Exile handled this in the most elegant manner to date - your potions are flasks which are permanent items which carry a set number of charges. You consume X charges and it performs an effect, such as healing you or refilling your mana. Killing enemies restores the charges in your flasks, so you can run out during a fight, but you can also refill stuff as long as you're continually killing stuff. This allows a great deal of control for the designers on boss fights by allowing for smaller enemies to spawn to refill flasks, but also for control over what flasks do. They're not just limited to healing health and mana, but can also give defensive bonuses, speed boosts, even damage increases. You can even get unique flasks with specialized properties.  This is only one change made, but it represents a large portion of what makes PoE so important of a game: the mechanics are elegantly designed and fine tuned to make the game more fun in the direction it intends to head. It's built to encourage you to move from pack to pack of enemies, tearing through them and moving onto the next batch with as little downtime as possible. Even the level design, despite being procedurally generated, is set up in such a way that there're almost always an intuitive feel to where you're supposed to go. Following a road or river will usually get you where you want to go. If there's a crossroads with the world map saying there's exits to the north, east, south and west, then if you explore the four cardinal directions, heeeey there you go, there's exits on each side of the game map. There's not a whole lot of wandering around aimlessly and being unsure of where to go - the trick is more getting to where you want to go in one piece.  There's a lot of other major upgrades over other games. For example, the loot system is such that you can remake virtually any item that drops. Change the sockets on it, the colour of the sockets, the stats, the item quality, you name it. You can basically reroll anything you want on an item until it works. You also have a stash which innately allows the transferrance of items between characters, and it's not a small stash either, having 4 rather hefty tabs which can hold an awful lot of stuff by default. You can, of course, purchase additional stash tabs, but unlike most free to play games, they don't penalize you with a pitifully small stash where you feel forced to get more tabs - it's biiiiig by default, and buying more tabs is really just for hoarders like... uhm. Me. Even so, it's still a ton of space so it's hard to be upset with it.  There are unique game modes as well which change fairly often. As of the writing of this, the current game mode has packs of frozen enemies appear 1-3 times per map where the enemies will have one rare monster with stronger abilities and a pack of smaller enemies. Unfreeze them by poking the ice 3 times and they attack - kill them off and they drop a handy item which can be used to upgrade any normal item into a rare with a pre-set stat based on the item used to upgrade. Yes, you can customize your gear easily this way so that you never really have garbage laying around waiting for a good drop.  Other handy things include stuff like how items are broken into one of six categories: strength, dexterity and intelligence, with hybrids between each of these. Strength focuses on armour for reduced physical damage taken. Dexterity is evasion where you just don't get hit in the first place, and intelligence has an energy shield which gives you a second health bar which regenerates quickly once you stop getting hit. This makes each ideal to what they're supposed to do defensively, and fully supports the idea of hybrid characters.  To go with this, weapons themselves have specific effects built into the weapon themselves. Staves have an innate block chance to make up for not having a shield for instance, or daggers increase critical hit chance, claws innately lifesteal, swords have a bonus to accuracy, maces increase stun duration while scepters increase the elemental damage dealt by melee attacks for non-physical damage builds, or wands increase spell damage or cast speed. Even shields may have bonuses, such as innately reflecting damage. The point is that each weapon actually serves a unique function and is built around such so that you can play whatever style you want to.  The 'classes' in the game are much the same way - any character class can do anything you want. Want a full plate armour witch with a two handed maul? ...You can do that. Slightly less efficiently than another character may, but she can totally do it. The difference between classes is primarily the skill gems they can purchase easily, and their starting location on skilldrassil.  I'd love to go into more detail but... I actually ran out of character limit so I can't. Oh well.  The point is that PoE is free to play and NOT pay to win, like this's one of the very few games that you can literally play start to end for free without microtransactions at all and they don't penalize you for it. You just get nice bonus stuff for paying, but you never feel like you're missing out because you didn't. The mechanics are exceptionally well designed and quite clever, the game is fast and fun, and works great with friends. It's built with hardcore diablo players in mind, and as you get farther into the game, it keeps introducing more and more new elements to the game play to keep things interested, even for high level players. It has a bit of a high skill floor for new players, so it can be a little rough to get started, but if you like having lots of stuff to keep learning to keep you interested that's not really that big of a problem.  In short, for the type of game they're building... it's pretty much perfect. Path of Exile scratches exactly the itch that Diablo 3 didn't. It just isn't really ideal for newbies is all.

Path of Exile might easily cause a bad first impression - the combat and movement at early levels feels slow and limited. But it gets better.  The skill system here allows for a lot of creativity in combining different gems, and the passive skill tree is a nice addition to make leveling up more interesting than most current Action RPGs that don't have any sort of real customization.  Combat at higher levels feels fluid and allow for many different playstyles, and the game can be quite challenging at times for those that like Hardcore or just dislike dying in general. The way it deal with 'seasons' (called Leagues here) is nice, and the fact that Hardcore characters aren't instantly deleted on death, but instead transfered to the permanent softcore league, is an interesting change.  Crafting might feel overly-complicated at first, but it's actually a pretty interesting system that allows you to have some fine control over your gear, instead of fully relying on random drops alone.  Another strong point of Path of Exile is that it is truly free to play. The cash shop here is something that you'll only ever spend money on if you wish to support the game.

Amazing game that offers a variety of things suited for multiple types of players. Although the game itself is a hardcore experience and takes significant time investment, due to active community, there is a plethora of ways for casual players to fully experience it, have fun and start their journey towards more in-depth gaming.   Game is so diverse with it's unique skill gem system that enables you to play pretty much anything, to various degree of success, depending on the quality of your theorycrafting. It offers hardcore mechanical gaming for players who prefer that, but it also offers a social trading experience for player who prefer to pile up gear over grinding experience and reaching max level content. Both ways equally rewarding and both ways require different skillsets. For new players it offers numerous cheap and accessible builds, enabled by heavily engaged streaming community which is probably most viewer based community i have witnessed. You can find your cheap, easy run of the mill build to enjoy this game in matter of minutes just browsing stream vods, and you can also find full game guides, sometimes hours and hours long.  The gameplay and mechanics itself are highly addictive with some really unique and interesting skills. Almost every aspect of your standard RPG is not only viable but customisable to the point i have never seen before.   Developers of the game are highly engaged with community, always seeking out advice on what the community wants but still having a firm grasp on what they considered balanced and not risking the integrity of the game core whilst trying to make their customers as satisfied as they can. The drive to make their game better and better every day is rivaled perhaps only by Riot games in todays market. I expect amazign things to come because with such focused developers this game can get nothing but better
