I've been playing this game off and on since Beta, never finishing it for whatever reason (probably the character resets), but always in awe of what Grinding Gear Games have accomplished. The Passive Skill Tree is massive, the skill gem system is flexible and rewarding, and the barter economy makes currency drops (the various 'orbs' of the game) exciting and fresh.   As far as the theme of the game goes, I feel it more closely resembles the oppressive darkness and hopelessness of Dark Souls than it does its spiritual forebear Diablo II. This feeling is only cemented by the cryptic lore, the impossibly ancient dungeons and crypts, and the merciless denizens therein. Though some criticize the game for being generic, I feel the atmosphere (including the solid soundtrack) are spot on and the environmental design ought to be applauded.   Were this game $60, I would recommend it to any fan of the genre (It may very well be the finest ARPG ever crafted and only promises to get better with constant updates and added content). But it is not $60... it is free. And I don't mean 'free' as in 'grind for hours or pay X amount of money for exp boosts or rare find boosts, but truly, wonderfully free. Nothing in the transaction store gives an in game advantage. Quite literally, it is all cosmetic. Perhaps one could argue that increased stash space is necessary, but the free amount of space is very generous and I could see playing for hundreds of hours without needing to expand. As it stands, there is nothing stopping you from playing this game save indifference to the genre. If you're even remotely interested in the game, download it.  This brings me to my only potential negative. The game is so free, in fact, that I'm terrified GGG isn't making anything from it. There is so little incentive to purchase any of the cosmetic items (which are, I admit, rather pricey), that I have to wonder how GGG are financing the game. I intend to buy something eventually (out of sheer guilt for getting to play such a great game for free), so my only hope is that enough others are of like mind to fund this game into the future.  tl;dr: Game is incredible and truly free. Try it. 10/10

Path of Exile is a weird game. It's characteristics are mostly both pros and cons.  * huge maps *  good, because you have more mobs, more way to travel, and generally more bad, because if you want to find something it takes ages * huge amount of mobs * good, because it's a challenge and additional loot bad, because it's a mindless challenge, chop chop 100s more mobs for nothing substantial * map reset / mobs respawn * good, because it gives you more mobs to kill, more ground to cover bad, because you have to walk again through the whole huge map to find the paths you already found * huge skill tree * good, because it's add variety and requires planning bad, because in practice you should use a few cookie cutter builds only unless you want to get stomped * dark design * good, because grim is how the game like this should look like bad, because sometimes it's actually nice to see where you're going or what's hitting you  Also for me the fighting is not meaty enough, it consists of basic attacks with occassional special skill. I'm sure it changes later in the game, but tens of hrs of simple chop chop is a bit discouraging. And sometimes you will die for no apparent reason as mobs will one-hit you out of the blue. This is probably due to desynch and not the game design, but it's still annoying.  TL;DR The game is good, just not fun.  You might be surprised that I don't really like the game that much, but I am still recommending it. Well, it is free and it is a quite good ARPG. I don't have hundreds of hours to sink into this, but if you have, it might be a very good title. Anyway it is well worth the admission price :)

This game, oh god this game. <3  Where do I even begin? Let's start with the good, no, the great!  'The Great'  The presentation, is exactly what it should be. It doesn't try to wow you at the begining with a flashy high res God of War styel fight, it doesn't promise amazing graphics and realistic worlds, but what it does give you is consistancy. From what I've seen so far the game developers knew exactly what kind of budget they had to work with, what styel they wanted the game to have, and they stuck to it. The gameplay is just like diablo, with clicking to move and fight all from a 3D Isometric top down perspective. The NPCs, at least the ones I've come across so far, do all talk in text boxes, but they all have full naration with colorful accents that make them feel so much more real than any animated cutscenes could. The world feels like it's alive. While being broken up into different sections by gates, you still walk through the maps as if you were actually travling across a sprawling landscape, fighting off monsters and canibals at every turn. And switching between areas or vilages doesn't reset these areas. You'll travle back through them and see the leftover corpses and gear of fallen enemies. It makes the world you play in feel even more real. Quests require real work, not just grinding the same 'levels' over and over again like some free to play MMOs have you do. Grouping up with friends is relatively easy but there are some gripes I'll hit on later, speaking of.  'The Not-so-good'  Now I mentioned how the different areas don't reset imediately after you leave them, well this can be a problem sometimes with certain quests, mainly when you're playing in a party and the quest requires each person to collect a set of items in a certain area. I ran into this problem fairly early on in gameplay where, I would have part of the items needed to continue, and another friend had the other items. It was very much a 'first come first serve' ordeal, which isn't exactly prime for a multiplayer setup. Another thing that I find a little annoying is the Leagues system, which keeps players divided from eachother. If you have a friend you want to group up with but they're in a different league than you are, then too bad. You can't change you'r character's league either, you have to make an all new character in that chosen league. Another, albeit minor, issue I've noticed is with how the game handles trafic towns. To keep the player traffic managable in the various villages, they run different instances. Not a bad thing of course, but when players join parties, they won't always see eachother. It won't switch you from your current instance to the instance that the party is joining in, even if you're in the same town. The only way I've found around this is while you're in the group, leave the town, then re-enter it and it /should/ put you into the proper instance where you'll find the rest of your party. A minor gripe as I said, but a gripe none the less.   All in all, I'd say this game is worth playing. Is it perfect? No, not at all. But it is a fantastic gem in the Free to Play market. If you're looking for a good dungeon crawller, or just a really invigorating game to play with your friends, then I can't recomend this game enough. Path of Exile, is at the very least, a must try.

I'm on my Merciless playthrough now and this game has been good. The first half of act 1 is ok and always made the game seem very average to me when compared to TQIT, but I stuck to it and progressed through each of the Acts and found Act II and III to be much, much better with the rest of Act 1 to be good. What does make this game awesome though is the way the socket system and the skill system works. It's very customisable and I can build my character the way I like. The community and guides online are also great for the game.   The game is very addictive and if you want a game that D3 could have been, this is it.    If I was to rate it out of 10, I'd give it a 7 because even though it's addictive there are a few things about the game that are a bit too irksome to give a higher rating:  Some people love it and some people hate it, but I'm not really a fan of the bartering system because I find it a bit restrictive with vendors. This also means that there is less variety at the vendors and I always liked saving up for and buying a massive item at a vendor in games like D1, D2, Torchlight 1 & 2 and TQIT.  Every time a legendary item drops, it would be amazing for 20 levels ago or it's amazing for another class. I haven't had a decent legendary drop yet and this is disappointing.   The currency items are hit and miss as well because I can enhance and item, but in order to get the item right I have to use a monumental amount of these and I find that not enough are dropping to create amazing items that are becoming more and more important as I play though. The most frustrating of these is the Orb of Fusing, which will always fuse 2 sockets together on an item, but any more than this and they get used up very quickly. In combination with Jeweller's and Chromatic orbs, this makes for very tedious and often disheartening results.   I feel the game also needs a respec NPC, rather than using Orbs of Regret. I find that as the difficulty levels get higher and the game gets harder, it becomes more and more important to have specific character skills from the skill web in order to keep progressing. This game is notorious for getting very, very hard at the higher difficulty levels (more so than most other RPG's) and this means that people need to experiment and respec more often to keep moving forward. Unfortunately in order to do so in POE, the only way to reclaim allocated skill points is to use Orbs of Regret. These are like hen's teeth because they don't drop very often and are only given on a few quests as rewards by NPC's. They can also be bought at vendors in towns, but the trade cost is monumental. This means that people have to farm to get enough orbs to reclaim points from certain lines in the skill web to allocate elsewhere and often the skill points will need to be reclaimed again because the new line(s) of skills aren't working and the only way to find out how well they work is through experimentation. This leads to more need for farming and can make the game very, very tedious indeed. The other way to get a good build is to copy other people's builds, but that takes away from the pleasure of creating and discovering one's own build.  I also find that the bosses are either too easy to kill or impossible to kill, with no inbetween. The easiest way to kill the easy bosses is to spam them head on, which works really well to break attacks and kill them quickly. The impossible to kill bosses are impossible to kill without dying because they have attacks that you can't dodge (like the whole scene filling with blood rain that does huge damage, or combo attacks with no room to dodge that are too fast to run from) and in order to kill these bosses, the only way to do it is to use a spam, die, spam, die, spam, die... victory technique. Just make sure you level before killing the boss to not loose to many exp points. Both of these methods feel very anticlimactic.   Some special monsters also come with elemental damage reflection, which is just downright annoying and completely unecessary because it defeats the purpose of having an elemental damage build. The only way to kill these specials is to use elemental damage and LOTS of healing or waste valuable skill points on a physical attack skill that does SFA damage anyway. Also, the game (rightfully so) sends wave after wave of monsters, which means that you kind of just get into a rythm of attacking constantly using similar patterns without really looking at each individual monster unless they don't die as fast as they should. This means that you won't see or notice the special with the elemental damage reflection until it's too late and you've dropped your flame totem and your aoe spells into the mob. Then, all of a sudden, you die and that's why it's really annoying!  The devs also wanted to have a d2 style inventory management system, which is nostalgic, but players have moved on and it would have been better to have a more modern system with more space.  I'm also not really a fan of how my town portals disappear and how I need to redo an area if I've been in a side area for longer than 15 minutes and come back to it.   The servers have also had some stability issues and POE seems to have a lot more lagg than it should.

Simple review: This game is what Diablo 3 should have been.   Thorough review: Maybe a little overly complex for an entry level player, but for someone who has enjoyed games like this for a while it is awesome. Gameplay can be challenging if you want it to be. If you do not want it to be, you just re-run lower level areas to get ahead of the game in loot and experience. The potion system is a great renovation, which I think is a big game changer. Lots of spells and abilities to choose from. Leveling up spells by actually getting experience while having them equiped, very cool idea. Non-class system, interesting, but can be daunting for someone who is new to the genre. Honestly, my only complaint is that if you want to be a necromancer you cannot summon a full army of darkness. You get quite a few pets you can summon at once, but not a full army. Also, respeccing would not be easy, so plan ahead before putting points anywhere.  On the fact is a F2P game: I do not play many F2P games, this is the exception. This feels like a game I paid for. In fact, it is much better than games I have paid for (I am looking at you Diablo 3). It is in no way a 'Pay to win' business model. I've not purchased any items in this game so far, because nothing has really looked appealing to me. I probably wouldn't use most of those items if they were given free. I'd like to see some skins, permenent weapon effects (glows, change skin, etc), and skill animation changes. Things that do not effect gameplay, but make it more fun. It has been a while since I looked in the item shop, so things may have changed.

Areas feel different and varied, and the execution of how you can either go solo or with friends really caught my eye in making the world feel just at home with someone wanting to play single player, but have multiplayer mechanics there to hop into at basically any time. The higher difficulties feel well balanced too, only running into one type of enemy that felt like a wall while the rest had the right amount of challenge to be invigorating, but not frustrating; rewarding, but without driving you to the point of rage.   Now with the nitpicks; The sphere grid is enormous, and even though I was familiar with the gameplay style I wanted, constantly felt unsure what was the best path to take, and whether that path would see me all the way through. I found myself more often than not having the chat off due to divisive topics with immature reasonings being argued, among other things.   All in all, I still immensely enjoyed the experience, and could easily recommend the game, especially with it being free-to-play. Being a fan of Diablo I felt enough at home to hop right into some of the mechanics, but was greeted with enough new tweaks and additions to where the experience felt unique rather than copied. I can't rate a game based on its community, so that only leaves one nitpick and a solid 8/10 from me.

Each character class does not get their own skill set, but rather a skill category. Skills are used by finding any 3 types of gems, blue gems (for more magic based classes), red gems (for more warrior type classes) and green gems (for more rogue type classes). Gems can be accuired by completing quests and looting mobs. The currency system is very good, the main type of money is scrolls of wisdom. Scrolls of wisdom can be used to buy items from merchants or to identify the hidden values of an item in your inventory. Path of Exile is one of the best free to play games I have played and I would recommend it to anyone who likes RPG's.

This is what we were waiting for. For what seems like a decade, we have been waiting for the next Diablo game to come out. Diablo III was finally released, and while many touted it as a good game, it was overall a disappointment. Which is why it is so much more satisfying that a F2P game hit steam and outdid itself. This game is being promoted by many (myself included) as what Diablo III was supposed to be. It is one of the bravest games I've seen during my 'gaming career' so to speak. One giant passive tree on which to build your character and a bunch of skill gems help to piece the rest together.   Grinding Gears Games offers a promise of never being pay to win by offering purely cosmetic items to purchase. With the game being absolutely free, there is no reason not to give it a try and I highly recommend that those of you into RPGs give it a go. There are numerous character classes that can be built any way you want them to.. Even though it doesn't make sense to be a summoner when you roll as a marauder, you could do it if you really wanted to. I said that it was brave because PoE is offering a fresh take on RPGs with a passive tree that is used for all of the classes, albeit starting in different areas of the tree. During your time in the game you will search for gems which will help you gain access to new abilities, while still providing the thrill of getting that long-awaited piece of gear you've been searching for.   The game gets more difficult as you go, there are 3 difficulty settings and as you make your way through all of them, you will start needing to think a little before you walk into the next room. Currently we are on Act 3 in cruel, which is the second difficulty, and I'll tell you right now; It is difficult without having someone there to help take damage. 3 damage-based builds are nice, but they mean nothing if you can't get off more than one or two spells before being slaughtered.   The only negative to this game is rubber bands. I can't even count how many times I thought I was hitting a mob of baddies and it turned out I was 10 feet away and almost dead. The server issues are mostly likely attributed to the fact that the game is free to play, and unfortunately may never be fixed. Developers must certainly be worried about allowing players to host their own servers when playing with friends because it would become much easier to exploit the game, which is unfortunate to say the least.   All in all I highly recommend this game as it is free to play, if you don't like it after hitting level 20, then maybe this just isn't the game for you, but all you'll have lost is a few hours, not $40.00 for a similar game. If it weren't for the lag issues this game would get a perfect score from me, as it is I have to give it a 9/10.

As a former Diablo 3 player (and still play casually), I hate to admit it, but Path of Exile exceeds almost everything that Diablo 3 has in terms of gameplay.   In an ARPG, customization is a huge part of the game and PoE has a gigantic skill tree for you to build whatever character you want. Another thing that I really enjoy about this game is the 4-month seasons that bring new ways to experience the game from new enemies and affixes or buffs. It really makes the game stay fresh and you can't help but keep coming back for more. On top of that, this game updates very frequently and it's hard to believe this thing is completely free and no pay-to-win at all.  There are so much more to the game that I don't want to go into great detail about; otherwise it would end up being an essay. First - PoE is free to play but not 'pay to win' so there is no reason for you not to try it out. You can stop reading and start playing now or get some impressions below:   PoE follows in the steps and is clearly inspired by Diablo 2 though with some MMO-elements like timed events and competitions. Some might claim it is the spiritual heir to Diablo 2 which is open to heated debate since Diablo 3 alienated many old-time fans (simplified skill system, itemization issues, auction house). Anyway this a classic and well-executed action-RPG and you spend much time thinking about builds and item combinations.  Skill 'tree' is a huge labyrinthic pattern actually and you have to choose carefully which road to plot with your skill-points so you end up in the areas you want to skill. An ingenious idea and I hope to see more like that.  While passive skills and attributes are earned with level-up-points on the 'tree' classical active skills are available through gems which you socket in your items and they also level with fighting like you. Since sockets and gems come in red/green/blue flavours and also linked type gear selection becomes complex fun. A mace might have great damage but no red-blue linked sockets for example.  Because of this system any class can become any kind of fighter or mage but there are clear preferences depending on where the class starting point on the skill pattern. Like the witch starting with more magical choices and few melee options near the starting point. You'd have to use up skill points to arrive there.  There's no gold in the game. Items are sold for consumable item pieces like 1/8 identify scroll. Items are again bought with consumable items like a whetstone which you could also use up to improve your gear. Choices again...  PoE works great with friends but also single-player however you still have to be on the server to play with the usual disadvantages such as lag, disconnects and down-times. (I'd pay them to have an offline single player mode) Also after a few minutes the areas/instances are reset so if you spend too much time shopping you might start back at the last waypoint with fresh monsters and a new randomized map. The game is FREE however so I don't complain at all, right 60€-Blizzard?   Go play now.

Short form/TL;DR: A good Diablo-like game with MMO elements and an insanely complex progression system for the geekiest of gamers. Enjoying it quite a bit, and at the price, what's not to like! There are minor warts, but nothing to spoil the innovative and well executed gameplay features.  Long form:  Path of Exile looks like Diablo. It has click-to-move like Diablo. It has two status globes, one red for life and one blue for mana like Diablo. It has item rarities structured and colored like Diablo.  The comparisons go on and on. Path of Exile is an Action RPG very much styled after Diablo.  However, it's important to understand going in that this is not a Diablo clone. You'll see this most strongly at three points in the very first section:  1. When you kill the very first zombie that shows up on the starting beach, it will drop a gem for you to socket into your gear. This gem isn't a power-boost or enhancement. It IS your single starting class skill. In fact, all gems in the game are one of two things: class skills or enhancements to other skills. There are no other skills in the game, and all classes can use all gems if they've trained the requisite attributes for them.  2. When you first level up, you will be allowed to spend a talent point. At first, your eyes will bug out a bit because the talent tree is ... daunting. It's larger than your screen, even at good resolution and zoomed all the way out. It's a web of every possible talent for every class. That's right, no class gets their own talents. Classes are only there for two things: 1) aesthetics like character gender, voice work and size 2) where you start in the class web. Other than that, eveyone gets the same and every talent is passive. You will never get another button to press by taking a talent!  3. When you reach the starting town, you will want to sell your junk for gold... but there is no gold! Instead, you get these baubles that have special abilities like turning a normal item into a magic item or giving a magic item a new ability. These are the 'currency items' of the game and can be spent with vendors for gear, used to upgrade existing gear or saved for later, end-game uses. The fact that these items have a use of their own means that the usual 'gold sinks' required in MMO Action RPGs like Diablo 3 just go away in this game. People will 'spend' currency to either get higher level currency or upgrade items at the end-game, so it will constantly flow out of the economy, naturally.  Overall, this game is well balanced, excellently designed and a joy to play.  That said, it's not all roses. There are some drawbacks:  1. The game UI cannot be scaled except by having a higher resolution display. This is very annoying to players used to modern, scalable games. Similarly, windows can't be moved, the minimap (which is off by default, but can be turned on in the options) is non-interactive and many other expected UI features just aren't there (yet?... I hope.)  2. The 'microtransaction' store isn't. It ranges from around a buck for trivial, essentially useless things to $120 for a full package of features. In general, expect to spend about $20 for anything you might really have your heart set on like that nice pack of 6 extra tabs for your shared bank ('stash'). This will probably change, as right now there is very little reason for players to buy and almost none to buy more than once. Eventually the store will have to become a recurring revenue stream for them and will have to encourage even players with very little disposable cash to spend a little. One big positive though: there's absolutely no hint of pay-to-win!  3. The game can be very harsh at times. Your character's progress is advanced by completing objectives and by hitting 'waypoints' which you can teleport back to, but the locations of these waypoints is not always clear, and it's possible to get several maps in and die, only to find out that you missed a waypoint on the previous map!  4. The game has a very annoying shared loot system, similar to Diablo. This annoys me more than any other problem with the game, and is most of why I don't group with others very often. I'm just tired of seeing a nice item only to lose out to a melee player who is always going to click on the gear faster than I will because I'm standing at range. The game really needs a loot system that encourages playing with random people and not just your close circle of friends.

This is quite possibly one of the best F2P games that I've played in the last 5 years. The paid aspects is purely cosmetic, and a pure non-requirement towards progression, or a complete game.  As far as gameplay, this game is a Diablo Clone. However, the game integrates a series of mechanics to make it stand alone in an all-too-familiar genre: First, there is an expansive... and I mean expansive... passive skill system. A couple hundred to choose from and to progress through, akin to FFX styling. For active abilties, the game follows a materia-style system, where equipment has colored sockets, and you can match abilities, or supporting abilities to the corresponding colored sockets. Skills then proceed to level based on XP gain of the user.  All in all, the game definitely scratches the Diablo itch, and has increased replayability relative to the Diablo series due to the expansive passive skill system, and class selection. The fact that this game is free is borderline criminal (you can pay in microtransactions for some cute cosmetic features and the like but I have thoroughly enjoyed the game without doing so).   Yes, it's similar to diablo 3, but the way the games play are very different. In my opinion, the combat is a lot more visceral here; you can really feel the punch behind your weapon strikes. In addition, the way you customize your character (any class can use any skills as long as they meet certain attribute requirements) is actually quite ingenious and well-executed. The bartering system (there is no 'gold' in this game; you trade items for useful consumables and vice versa) is also accessble and is quite appropriate given the game's setting. It also acts as a natural countermeasure to inflation because the items you trade with (e.g., identify scrolls) are always useful in their own right.  If there's one complaint I have about this game, it's that the game can frequently lose synchronization, and you find yourself apparently striking the enemy when in fact you are swinging at air. This is solved through the slash command /oos but it still happens frequently enought to be of moderate annoyance.  However, that doesn't detract from the fun I've been having even playing this game casually. And at an outrageously low price of $0, you don't have much to lose by at least trying it.

For those loyal fans of Diablo 2 to play what Diablo 3 was expected to be. Path of Exile is a thinking mans Diablo. It has all the loot based dungeon crawling you could want. Bosses are challenging. There are numerous modes of play from Softcore, Hardcore and ever changing modes that get switched out every couple of months.   Many classes, albeit gender locked (why can't games learn to knock this crap off?) to choose from. An unlockable class. Skills are tied to gems you find and socket into your weapons. Passive skills are unlocked as you level up across a GIGANTIC skill tree.   The community might bash you for it. But It's advised that you research the skill tree before you roll a character.  Otherwise you risk wasting hours of play just to end up with a self-nerfed character that can't complete the later levels of the game.   That being said. If you know what you are doing. You can create insane builds that can trash the game. Become a god-like harbinger of death that wipes out entire groups of mobs in the blink of an eye.   Gear works much differently too. Socketed items are plentiful. But the color of the sockets and whether or not the sockets are linked play a big factor.  All those details aside. You'll get 3 Acts to beat and 3 levels of difficulty. With end game maps to loot and use to keep a fresh loot filled experience going.   Unique weapons are not like you would expect. This isnt Diablo 2. They are not all powerful items. Many of them have trade offs of having a lot of life, attack, or attack speed - but will lower you're resists, defense, magic find. This is just an example. Its sometimes frustrating. To pick up a long awaited Unique drop to find out the item is actually junk. Kinda like early Diablo 3 uniques being inferior to Rare's.   The game looks good, plays good. Its free. It supports guilds, trade and party play. The community can be annoying and immature at times. Plenty of trolls to feed.   Overall its a solid game. And its free. So there isn't any excuse to not try it out.

Path of Exile could scare alot of people away, it has a steep difficulty curve and a rather unique economy system. When you first open the skill tree it's very overwhelming, but it starts to make sense when you really get into the game. The skill tree is only passives. Spell and skill casting is done by aquiring gems which needs to be placed in equipment sockets. There are great resources and tutorial videos on the web.   The game has superb graphic quality but lacks alot of imagination and any interesting art direction. Generic looking monsters, few interesting. But considering their budget must have been 1/4 of a regular ARPG studio, this is pretty stellar work. On a brighter side this crowd funded game has been active and supported by the dev's religiously, which means it's worth investing time and money in.  What is respectable is that the game is not Pay to win, but you can pay for extra stashe tabs and cosmetics which is extremely fair which helps fund PoE.  The biggest issue with this game is the DeSync and it does suck when it happens at a Boss map. There's also the Trade Chat which is overly busy and hard to follow, usually most players turn it off. The game also has spam in the chat leading to third party 'pay real money for unique equips' considering that the game is Free 2 Play it's easy for these spam sites to keep recreating accounts.   I'm not a fan of the Diablo series, but aware that the developers wanted a 'true' sequel to Diablo. The game has a great community, however the underage crowd has started to gather and makes you want to turn off the global chat. But I feel this game will continue to grow, and hopefully will get the needed polish it deserves.

An Isometric hack&slash in the style of Diablo 2, free to play without any gameplay restrictions.  The most asked question when choosing between different free to play games usually is 'What do I get for free ?' In path of Exile - you get the whole game, period. No restriction on classes, content and a very fair amount of characterslots (I haven't hit the cap, having around 5 playable characters at a time) and four times the stashspace available in aforementioned Diablo 2.  Spending money will get you visual distinction in the form of unique item effects like flaming swords or golden halos around your head, more storage space for yourself or your guild or , for those with a lot of disposable cash at their hands - a unique item,monster or mechanic you design with the developers.   There are no game influencing items for sale. No experience boosts or better chances form magic items - nothing you can buy in the store has a mechanical influence on the game.  The game itself evokes flashbacks from days gone by - the world feels desolate and hopeless, with gore and brutality all around. Which is not to say that the game would look bland or ugly - quite the opposit. The engine presents the continent of wraeclast in a lot of detail, with sufficient lighting and particle effects to stand among modern titles.  It does not come close to the visually impressive Diablo 3 though, which might be an issue for those seeking the latest and greatest in visual fidelity.  The story of Path of Exile is simple at first, with a few twists and revelations strewn in throughout the campaign. It is interesting to listen to, offering a decent amount of background and 'fluff' through optional NPC conversations and objects throught the maps. The story won't rewrite the genre - but it takes some risks and provides a unique perspective  The gameplay is satisfying to say the least - skills are gained through gems offered as questrewards or monsterdrops and can be combined to alter the effects and usability of skills, giving players an unlimited amount of possible combinations. Aside from skills, characters gain passive skillpoints for each level, with choices ranging from mundane '+X life' to completly game changing 'convert all evasion to armor' for examples.  These system offer players chances to customize their characters in a myriad ways - some more viable then others, but each unique. If nothing else, this will set the game apart from diablo 3's prebuild characters.  For players seeking a challenge beyond the (for my taste) quite steep progression beyond the first playthrough, the game offers unique events from week to week - challenging players to run characters through custom dungeons in the fastest way possible, without access to a town etc.  For casual hack&slash players, the skill and passive system might look intimidating at first, but it only takes an hour or two to find your way through it until you'ld be able to build the character of your dreams.  In summary - I recommend this game to casual fans of the genre as well as seasoned veterans as everyone will find a worthwhile experience. The amount of brutality on display is not suitable for minors or those faint of heart. Those might want to check out Torchlight 2 instead.  As always - no rating. Judge the game by how many hours of entertainment it gave you.

Overall, if you're looking for a dark ARPG that won't wreak havoc on your wallet, give this one a try!

Path of Exile is a dungeon crawler click 'em up brought to us by New Zealand Developers 'Grinding Gear Games'. It draws inspiration from various games such as Diablo and Torchlight II yet still has enough in there to feel like a new game. Gameplay, Art Style and even the voice acting and sound design all nail the dark and gloomy dungeon crawler vibe. There are currently 5 classes to play with an unlockable 6th. Each class can become anything throughout the game though so what you're really picking is where you want to start on the (very large) skill tree. So sit back, drink your co-coa, yell to your mom your reading something and let me tell you my tales of Path of Exile...  So this game seemed okay (and free, with purely cosmetic micro-transactions) so install it I did. Fairly small-ish game coming in at 5-6GB so it only took me a few hours. The first thing I noticed when opening up the game was how beautiful the loading screen was. Rain puring down with sad music playing in the background with 'Path of Exile' in 3D text. A good start but I guess a loading screen can't mean much. I created an account and was then forced to choose a class. I chose shadow and quickly went through 2 or 3 quests (up to level 5) before I quit, deleted him and decided to make a witch. I was seeing all of these summon items and I thought rasing an army of my own would be cool but the summon passives where next to the witch. A new character was okay at that point, I didn't even have any good gear. Upon creating a character (listening to the witches back story first of course) you're confronted with the shores of a beach. Nothing really happens and I'm sitting there staring at the screen for half-a-minute before I think to click. My character, MrKadius, coughs and gets up. A survivor sits up on a log. He tells me what I must do before the dead guy next to him bites his head off and I'm left to fend him off with my new-found 'Driftwood Wand'. As I wonder down the beach I'm confronted by more of the 'Drowned' and a few little spider things that have poop guns built into them or something. After a while of clicking and sometimes right-clicking I found myself at this giant zombie boss. He was easy enough and killed him first try. I met up with some friends of mine I was talking with and their characters. Our total group was a Marauder (tank), Hunter (archer) and a Templar (healer type guy). We made a good team but I must say, this game with a party is far too easy. We breezed through the whole of act one with no one even getting CLOSE to dying. The challenge did not come until Act 2. The first death we had was when we were actually forced to choose between helping a guy (three of them across the map) or killing him. The two sides of the party must fight to the death. This is actually the way most of us died for the first time. I managed to survive but only because my summons where being meat shields while i attacked with my fireball reign of death. We ended up calling it a night after that quest. We continued playing... thoughout the month... until Act 3.  It was a fun Journey to endgame (we're still noobs). This game is fun polished and insanely clutch in Act 3. I keep getting on and running some maps every now and then so it has replay ability. Then one day, I was going to log on and reluctantly hit create.  Brilliant. 9.5 out of 10

Path of Exile is a phenomenal game. I have roughly 3000 hours played (before linking to Steam), and I can honestly say it is my favorite game of all time.  Combining classic Diablo II with modern ideas and gameplay, Path of Exile boasts a diverse skill tree, a seemingly infinite number of skill combinations, and an innovative crafting and currency system.  With a steep learning curve, and an unforgiving skill system, the game is challenging for new players. Fortunately, the community is mostly full of helpful people, including a well-documented wiki, a variety of great streamers, and guides to the game all around the internet.   Trading is, sadly, the most-lacking area of the game, and also one of the most integral. Use of third-party sites and tools is allowed - encouraged, even - by Grinding Gear Games, but hopefully they'll implement their own system.  If you enjoy aRPG's, this is definitely one to try.

Very solid game with a unique mechanic for skills. Each character has a different starting point on a 'grid' with tons of passive bonuses, most of which are small, but a few that can completely change the way you play. Each character is easily able to reach another characters section of the passive skill tree, so you can play in any way you want, though it may not be optimal  The active skills and spells that you make use of to attack come in the form of colored socketed gems, which you can combine together to make new skills, if your armor's sockets are linked together in the correct way, and the correct color to hold said gems. Part of the fun of the game is getting the perfect armor piece for the skill you want to mix together  Unlike other games of the Genre, this game does not use a 'currency' system in the traditional sense. Instead, it uses a barter system based on 'orbs' which can be traded, or used to modify your equipment, such as adding sockets, changing the color of Sockets, reforging the magical stats on your equipment, and many other effects.  The cash shop is non intrusive, and is filled with thing that are not remotely necessary for normal play, such as alternatative skill visual effects, cosmetic armor skins, and extra stash tabs, though the game does start you with 4 large tabs, which I have personally never been able to fill.  Aesthetically, the game is very similar to Diablo 2, with a dark, realistic artstyle, though obviously, much less dated.  Finally, the staff and support team are very active and friendly, updating the game and fixing bugs consistantly, and responding to support inquiries very quickly.

If you do not have a mainstream AAR to play, this is a very good choice as it features a very addictive gameplay and leveling aspects that, despite being repetitive in gameplay are still an enjoyable experience. If you enjoy storylines and following a campaign, this game is not for you. The animation is clunky, verging on completely lacking smooth biological motions, and models lack detail. Also you will be playing a tank at the current patch (1.0.1) regardless of any 'build' you attempt, making half of the shared passive talent tree essentially completely worthless. The 'skill gems' are identical to 'materia' (compared to FF7), and you will find yourself using the same 2, maybe 3 active skills just like any other AAR. In addition, the primary form of survival will still be potion mashing, and while they use charges you will find yourself using town portals as part of boss mechanics to refill your potions. This aspect is excessively bad design, as most classes are unable to sustain themselves against higher difficulty bosses causing what should be epic battles to be interrupted, further put down by the fact that because of this your character should essentially never die which removes any desire as a self-proclaimed hardcore game. Programming errors are also quite abound, as rubberbanding will happen indefinitely to both your character and the mobs you are engaged in. You may also, for example, find yourself spamming a ranged ability at a group of mobs in a doorway only to find that for some unexplainable reason they are not being affected by your ability. Finally, the community is absolutely atrocious due to the free-to-play nature, with only a small handful of players who actually get far enough into the game to make a proper judgment. The bulk of the game population are those who did not enjoy other AAR games (for whatever reasons) and therefore continually spam global channels with arguments and comparisons.  This game is not a substitute for Torchlight, Diablo, Titan Quest, or any other of the classic AAR games as it does not offer even half of the variety and expanse as these games do, in almost every aspect. Because of it's complete lack of a proper class system (not a bad thing) it has no place being compared to other AAR games which feature self-sufficient classes functioning in unique ways to stay alive without relying on potion mechanics. This game 'sells' on being free and having an (enjoyably) easy initial playthrough, after which most players seem to quit as they realize they do in fact have to follow a very narrow selection of builds (just like any other AAR) and have essentially 'screwed up' their character in the passive tree.  Now for the good points; this game is highly addictive, as stated before, and all of the problems listed above are fixable with balancing patches and service updates. Being able to mix and match gems such as 'curse on hit' or 'cast spell when damage taken' are what save the skill gem features, and instead of focusing solely on the stats on gear you are rewarded more for having good sockets/links for your abilities. The higher difficulties are challenging, and while there is little variety in what you are doing (if any), you will still enjoy smashing a giant group of mobs with dynamic spells and ability chains. There is also supposed to be regular content updates every two weeks, and an expansion for early 2014 planned, which are some of the key points which save the approval rating for this game.  78% approval

'A game that takes a minute to learn, but a lifetime to master.'  That was the quote on a game of Othello that my Grandpa gave me. Path of Exile really fits the same theme. You install the game, pick a class, wake up on a stranded island, zombies everywhere.... ok good so far. Then you pick up your first weapon with some sockets and a gem and you're like 'Hey, I've seen this before...' but the gem gives you skills instead of stats so that's kind of cool. And so you whack a few mobs and it's fine, but then it happens - you've reached level 2. You gain a 'passive' skill point represented by a little plus sign at the bottom of the screen. And so you go to click on it to place your skill like so many games before and it is at this point where your jaw drops off your face.  The skill tree is like a mandala. An interwoven tapestry of perks, stat points, and modifiers. As you hastily scroll around you get the feeling like choosing any number of different nodes could lead to a completely different experience. It's like the game designers thought of the game's evolution similar to some monks plotting paint out in a Tibetan monastery.  And so your journey begins.....  Overall, I have to give this game a 8.5/10. There are many excellent, excellent things about this game - including the coveted 'fun' factor. But there are some glitches in the games mechanics, such as desyncs and somewhat dated graphics, that hold it back from perfect. Also, I'd really like a better method of trading in game than trade chat.  What do I like? The complexity and the simplicity. For instance, you get your skills from gems. Those gems can increase in level as you gain experience, so maybe your fireball spell goes from level 1 to level 2. Pretty simple, right? Well, maybe later on you come across a new type of gem - a 'support' gem. Maybe this gem increases the impact radius of another gem. So slot that puppy in on a linked piece of equipment with the fireball gem and BOOM, bigger explosions. What's next? Well, maybe you want to shoot more than one fireball with an increased chance to ignite monsters into walking candle sticks - yes, please! What's better? Get that gem to level 20 and you can vendor recipe it for an improved quality gem that makes for even better fireballs.   I could go on, but I think it is best to put this in a frame work of other similar titles out there. Path of Exile is what Diablo 3 should have been. It is simply the greatest spiritual successor to the enjoyment felt by Diablo 2 fans in that game's heyday.   Enjoy.

After playing extensivey for quite some time now I feel I am ready to write a review of my own for this game called Path of Exile. WHen it comes to games like this, it is very common for the average player to compare this game to DIablo 3, or the diablo series in general. I do not want to go to far in depth between these two games but essentially this is how I distinguish Diablo 3 and Path of Exile from one another.  Diablo 3 is the simplified RPG which is mainstreamed for casual gamers with incentives to continue playing for hardcore gamers. Path of Exile on the other hand is mainstreamed as a complex game for hardcore gamers with the ability to casually play the game. While DIablo 3 has some complexity depending on some legendary items you choose, Path of Exile takes complexity to another level with the passive tree, sockets in gear, links between gear, as well as skill gems. As such the chosen class plays a smaller role in the overall options available to each character. Since skills are gems you can use them on any character you want should you have the basic stat requirements to use them. This applies to all gear as well. As such creativity in builds based on class, gear, and skill trees is far superior than in Diablo 3 in its current state where essentially your max level set for your class is the current best set to use or to combine with a select few other legendary items.   Besides the complexity and flexibility in creativity that Path of Exile provides it also has created a currency system that does not depend on actual currency such as gold that is common in other games. Instead it uses actual items in the game that change statistical values or rarity of other items as currency. The more rare the item is the more valuable, as such Mirror's of kalandra are the most valued item in the game based on its likelihood of dropping as well as its ability to make a complete copy of an item to trade or sell to others.  Path of Exile also makes sure to always keep the competitive feeling high in the game. While Diablo 3 has recently added leagues, essentially the league system is a failure. It puts players against each other on the same base game as normal and the only benefit of playing on the league servers is for rankings, a poor skin set that you won't finish till season 4 (if you play all seasons to level 70), and a select few legendary items that eventually will be added to standard servers and arguably are not worth starting over for and waiting 2-3 months to get it on standard server. Path of Exile though always has lots of challenge leagues going add which give you points to get legendaries that you can't get anywhere else. Whether it is just a reskin of an item already in the game, or an entirely new one, it is always worth doing it since it will be valuable to sell to others later. Likewise placing high is rewarded even more which truly seperates yourself from those with less skill.  Finally Path of Exile actually does require some skill. In Diablo 3 there is no skill, essentially get your max level legendary set and you are good to go for torment 6. Path of Exile though no matter how good your gear is, you are still killable and you will eventually die. Even the best players in the game can and have instantly died during leagues when they never thought it was possible. Path of Exile is a learning experience and you will always be learning. There are always new things to try and then when you think you have tried it all there is always short length challenge leagues such as 1 hour endless ledge where you get to test your skills even more and show off how much you know about each character early game as well as how to level those characters the most efficiently early game to reach the highest level possible in the least amount of time.   In Short  Complex Flexible Creative Gaming = Path of Exile Simplified Easy Grinding Gaming = Diablo 3

Path of Exile (PoE) is an excellent hack and slash action RPG in a similar vein to the Diablo or Torchlight series.  The story takes on a bit of a darker tone, much like the earlier Diablo games. There's quite a bit of lore to be had in the NPC dialog and the various quests.  Some things that set PoE apart from the pack:    Free to play with a good micro-transaction shop, no pay to win here.    Quests are sometimes multi-faceted. Certain quests let you choose different outcomes.    Tons of optional content to be explored.    Active skills are socketable gems, and your repertoire of abilities can change as you play and enemies/chests drop new skill gems.    Gigantic passive skill tree completely separate from active skills. Similar to the sphere grid system from Final Fantasy X, where you can progress along a route of passive skills to reach the passive skill sets you want. Tons of customization and some really unique and game changing passive skills.    In game shop currency is based off of materials/components, rather than a gold/money system. +: Unlike its competition (Diablo 3, to a degree and for a time Torchlight 2) Path of Exile gives you plenty of reasons to re-roll the same character class many many times due to its sheer variety of skills and character builds that you can not respec easily. +: Graphically the game is awesome. +: The loot system is rather well done and feels very fair. This includes the monetary system which are orbs that you upgrade items with that people use as currencies to trade for other items. This makes a lot more sense to me than gold in an ARPG since Gold quickly becomes a useless resource - people used items in high end Diablo 2 trading as currencies anyways. This game just streamlined the process. +: The passive skill tree and skill gems are 10/10 amazing, deep complex systems that work fantastically and provide a lot of depth to character building. +: The flask system is a lot smarter replacement to potion spam in my opinion, and I prefer it to how Diablo 3 does it with the health orb / potion with a cooldown combo. +: The cash shop is completely fair and this is one of the few F2Ps (alongside DotA 2) where you get the actual entire game for free, everything else is just looks or minor convenience (like stash tabs). Zero pay to win. +: Limited time races for rewards and long duration leagues with special gameplay mechanics (that often get integrated back into the main game in all leagues) are amazing. +: The end game system of maps (with their own unique modifers and such that can affect the entire map) is pretty cool, and makes them more engaging than Rifts in Diablo 3. -: It does get a bit repetitive, but this is something a lot of ARPGs have problems with to be honest. Thankfully, it being free means you aren't really hurt much if you get bored of it for awhile.

They give up so soon they don't get the taste of the story, and then ofcourse say that story is boring. Struggles between hit and move, Finding a waypoint, etc.  Path of Exile could be not what you are used to. It may seem like an alien and you have to take it slow in order to not ♥♥♥♥ up ur character. Oh boy, this is gonna be a long one...  I can confidently start out a review for this gem of a game by saying that this game has ceased to disappoint me in any way. If you like games with a story, games with completely unique playability paths, huge skill trees, classes, valuable and currency, and more, then this game is a game you will enjoy.  STORY/PLAYABILITY: Basically, in this game, you get plopped into a somewhat complex storyline that has a bit of background you may want to read up on to really understand why you kill certain things, who you are killing, where you are going, and what you want to achieve by the end game. Once you do this, it is very interesting to see how the story plays out, and how you are able to accomplish goals. You complete the story mode/campaign a total of three times; each time gradually becoming more difficult and each growing in more consequences for each time you die. The three difficulties are Normal, Cruel, and Merciless. In normal, there are no consequences for dying, and in Cruel you lose 5% of your exp, and in Merciless you lose 10% of your exp for every time you die. It may not seem like alot, but it is aggravating when you realize how much you lose. Moving on, after you do beat the three difficulties, this game has EXTREME replayability. You can explore the new addition to the game; the Atlas. The atlas contains DOZENS upon DOZENS of maps in different tiers, getting harder every time you move on to a higher tier. At the end of the Atlas, you defeat someone of extreme difficulty. No spoilers here. Hehe...  CLASSES/SKILL TREE: This game has 6 different classes to choose from for different styles of gameplay. It has the Ranger, Shadow, Marauder, Duelist, Witch, and the Templar. Each of this having their certain spot on the skill tree to satisfy the play-style of each class. For example, the Witch is in such a place on the skill tree that has things like mana, mana regen, and mana cost close by as the Witch uses spells, mainly, that require mana. Same thing goes for the other player-types in this game. Although each character's appearance, gender, and personality are not customizable, they each have their own preset personalities and appearances that you do tend to get used to fast. What I love particularly is how humorous these characters can be as they react to killing an act boss.   PAY TO WIN OR PLAY TO WIN: Two words, absolutley not, this is a play to win game. This game does not contain any microtransactions that contain things that are required to advance in the game. However, you can buy cosmetic effects, pets, and account features that make the game even more enjoyable than it already is. For example, you can buy a cool little frog that follows you around in the game and you can buy armor effects or skins that alter the appearance of how you look ingame. They are very cool! Account features are things like extra stash tabs, extra character slots, things that make the game easier. None of these things limit you ingame.   CURRENCY: This game contains numerous forms of currency that all vary in value, rarity, and usability. Currency, in general, can be used to buy other items from vendors, or to customise your current equipment to fit your needs. Trust me, the amount of joy you can experience when a valuable piece of currency drops is amazing. Think of it like this, how would you react if you found a 50 dollar bill on the ground? Exactly the same as if an Exalted Orb dropped here.   PVP/OTHER PLAYERS: Players here can friend other players, form parties, join guilds, and complete the story together. Also, players may pvp eachother, or join the public arena. There are multiple forms of chat including Global, Guild, Whisper, and Party chat.   In all, I would definitley reccomend this game to anyone. I really do think it deserves more praise than it gets, and having played 200+ hours at the time of writing this post, I think I have made quite the trustworthy judgement. Check this game out if you crave a good game to play.

It is so odd to think that this game is free. Like absolutely 'Never, Ever, Ever Have To Pay A Dime' free. When I first signed up for Steam I recalled hearing about this game a few years back.... a game that was supposedly a well-done Diablo Clone with a Skill Tree that had literally hundreds upon hundreds of nodes.... allowing an unprecidented level of character depth. I did a little digging and found out the name of this game was Path of Exile. I decided to give it a whirl, finally having a decent enough computer to bother downloading Steam and get back into the pc games I'd been missing for the last few years while I sojourned in Console Land. What I discovered was NOT a Diablo Clone. It was a Diablo Killer. And that massive skill tree? Sure, it was there.... but it was only one of many, many things that Path of Exile got right.  Where Path of Exile and Diablo are similar is in that they are both Action-RPGs that lean upon the Kill-Loot-Levelup-Repeat schematic. What Path of Exile does is give you previously unknown levels of freedom in terms of developing your character. Any class can use any spells/weapons/armor/etc as long as they meet the level and stat requirements. That aforementioned massive skill tree has a Magic section, a Dexterity section and a Strength section but there are tons of sub-sections and tons of clusters of nodes here and there that you can 'travel' towards using your skill points.... meaning you can be a mage that eventually uses your skill points to link to the section that a straight-up Warrior/Fighter would have started at.... and then start putting points into stats and skills that said warrior would have been putting points into in the beginning of his/her character building. While you'll find people that swear that there is a 'best' way to build a given character... I've built maybe 4-6 characters so far and had a blast either picking whatever was my immediate 'best' choice for skills or finding areas of the skill-web (skill-tree just doesn't seem like an appropriate description) that I wanted to work towards and forgoing immediate benefit for long-term planning.... and even when I've used the same class I've ended up with wildly different characters.  The 'skill-web' i've referred to doesn't give you actual combat abilities.... for those you find Gems. Different melee attacks, magic spells, etc all come from gems either dropped from enemies, earned as rewards, or bought. That in itself doesn't sound too crazy.... but you can LINK the gems. Add ice effect to a fireball spell and turn your enemies into burning ice-cubes. Add lightning to a melee attack to electricute your enemies as you strike them. You can have up to 6-way links and there are more types of modifiers than i could list here. Turn a single fireball into a wave of fireballs..... then add poison to those fireballs. As you progress you get more and more unique abilities and modifiers.... summon zombies... then add a speed gem to make them faster, an ice gem to give them ice damage, a crit-up gem to make them more likely to score critical hits. I've yet to earn any of the truly legendary high-level gems or modifiers.... but they can get quite creative as you get into higher levels.  None of the aforemented details would matter if the game itself wasn't any fun. Let me assure you: I played a bit of Diablo 3 and found it pretty fun.... I never went back after playing Path of Exile. The moment-to-moment action is gratifying and challenging and you get loot and new skills often enough to make the grind worth it.... but you are not getting such a glut of stuff that you are awash with super-rare legendary gear. Unlike in Diablo 3 you won't necessarily find yourself leaning on 2 or 3 skills.... rather you'll have enough cool attacks that you will likely have to swap some out en mass when you get back to a hub.... especially since the gem-linking system highly rewards experimentation. The game designers are ALWAYS adding LOTS of new content..... and not little stuff.... like entire new chapters to the already lengthy campaign. They even give you all of the passive skill points back if they redo the skill-web so you can redo your skill points and take advantage of the new goodies they've added. This is the kind of dev that earns the good-will of their customers to where they'll pick up some cosmetic stuff in the Path of Exile online store just to support their work.... yes, they DO sell cosmetic in-game items but NOTHING that gives you any kind of advantage.  It's free.... so even if you give it a try and decide it's the worst thing every created by human hands: you have lost nothing except a little time... but it's quite possible you'll find your next favorite game.

'Path of Exile'  is a usual Hack&Slay/Action RPG like Sacred, Titan Quest, Diablo, etc.   TL;DR : Recommended. 8/10. It's for free, updates are often, sometimes new content and it has a high replayability because of it's temporary leagues and the skill tree freedom.     The long version     Desc:  The darkness tries a takeover and you are going to stop this madness. You fulfill quests like killing monsters to get rewarded with experience, gold, items. Killing monsters will do the same: dropping loot. You level up when your current XP reaches the maximum. A level up will give you skill points which can be invested into new skills. Until now there is nothing special about 'Path of Exile' - instead of the skill tree. As long as your character isn't a Scion your skill path is a bit fixed, but that doesn't matter. From here you are completly free by choosing your type of gameplay. Not like in any other RPGs you are not fixed to choose only between a double, tripple or a round attack as warrior. You can transform your warrior into a ranger, a mage or whatever you want him to be. Each play through will be in a certain league. There are permanent and temporary leagues. Each league has special abilities, like special items dropping only in this league or 'Slaying enemies in a killstreak grants Rampage bonuses'.  This freedom and the combination of leagues generates a really high replayability, because each character and each runthrough is different.   Pros:  + for free since beta (and will probably stay free) + infinity freedom creating characters to your needs + really nice skill effects + replayability by using leagues with special abilites for each league (+ to have a feeling of 'procedural' level design, they are twisting the map, interesting gambit) (+ steam achievements)   Cons:  - Story (as usual .. the darkness tries a takeover) - Mainquest has voice actors the rest is presented in scrolling textboxes   Recommended!    8/10

Let's get things out of the way first and foremost - Path of Exile is the true spiritual successor to Diablo 2, while Diablo 3 caters to a completely different play style and niche. Both are good games, but PoE is what D3 should've been.  With that out of the way, let's start with what PoE is. It's... an action-RPG dungeon crawler from a top-down isometic perspective. Or, in short, a Diablo clone. Which's not really a ringing endorsement in itself, but rather than it does everything the genre has set out to do but better.  There have been issues within the genre since it began. Mechanics which never quite worked right, which people have been attempting to solve for ages. For example, Diablo 3 introduced health globes where enemies tend to drop healing items at the end of a fight which you can pick up to restore your health so you can move onto the next fight quickly without slowing down. The 'danger' in combat should be centered upon the idea of running dry mid-boss fight, or during a single swarm of enemies, not being worn down gradually over time and being forced to head back to down, not even to drop off loot, but just to replace potions.  Path of Exile handled this in the most elegant manner to date - your potions are flasks which are permanent items which carry a set number of charges. You consume X charges and it performs an effect, such as healing you or refilling your mana. Killing enemies restores the charges in your flasks, so you can run out during a fight, but you can also refill stuff as long as you're continually killing stuff. This allows a great deal of control for the designers on boss fights by allowing for smaller enemies to spawn to refill flasks, but also for control over what flasks do. They're not just limited to healing health and mana, but can also give defensive bonuses, speed boosts, even damage increases. You can even get unique flasks with specialized properties.  This is only one change made, but it represents a large portion of what makes PoE so important of a game: the mechanics are elegantly designed and fine tuned to make the game more fun in the direction it intends to head. It's built to encourage you to move from pack to pack of enemies, tearing through them and moving onto the next batch with as little downtime as possible. Even the level design, despite being procedurally generated, is set up in such a way that there're almost always an intuitive feel to where you're supposed to go. Following a road or river will usually get you where you want to go. If there's a crossroads with the world map saying there's exits to the north, east, south and west, then if you explore the four cardinal directions, heeeey there you go, there's exits on each side of the game map. There's not a whole lot of wandering around aimlessly and being unsure of where to go - the trick is more getting to where you want to go in one piece.  There's a lot of other major upgrades over other games. For example, the loot system is such that you can remake virtually any item that drops. Change the sockets on it, the colour of the sockets, the stats, the item quality, you name it. You can basically reroll anything you want on an item until it works. You also have a stash which innately allows the transferrance of items between characters, and it's not a small stash either, having 4 rather hefty tabs which can hold an awful lot of stuff by default. You can, of course, purchase additional stash tabs, but unlike most free to play games, they don't penalize you with a pitifully small stash where you feel forced to get more tabs - it's biiiiig by default, and buying more tabs is really just for hoarders like... uhm. Me. Even so, it's still a ton of space so it's hard to be upset with it.  There are unique game modes as well which change fairly often. As of the writing of this, the current game mode has packs of frozen enemies appear 1-3 times per map where the enemies will have one rare monster with stronger abilities and a pack of smaller enemies. Unfreeze them by poking the ice 3 times and they attack - kill them off and they drop a handy item which can be used to upgrade any normal item into a rare with a pre-set stat based on the item used to upgrade. Yes, you can customize your gear easily this way so that you never really have garbage laying around waiting for a good drop.  Other handy things include stuff like how items are broken into one of six categories: strength, dexterity and intelligence, with hybrids between each of these. Strength focuses on armour for reduced physical damage taken. Dexterity is evasion where you just don't get hit in the first place, and intelligence has an energy shield which gives you a second health bar which regenerates quickly once you stop getting hit. This makes each ideal to what they're supposed to do defensively, and fully supports the idea of hybrid characters.  To go with this, weapons themselves have specific effects built into the weapon themselves. Staves have an innate block chance to make up for not having a shield for instance, or daggers increase critical hit chance, claws innately lifesteal, swords have a bonus to accuracy, maces increase stun duration while scepters increase the elemental damage dealt by melee attacks for non-physical damage builds, or wands increase spell damage or cast speed. Even shields may have bonuses, such as innately reflecting damage. The point is that each weapon actually serves a unique function and is built around such so that you can play whatever style you want to.  The 'classes' in the game are much the same way - any character class can do anything you want. Want a full plate armour witch with a two handed maul? ...You can do that. Slightly less efficiently than another character may, but she can totally do it. The difference between classes is primarily the skill gems they can purchase easily, and their starting location on skilldrassil.  I'd love to go into more detail but... I actually ran out of character limit so I can't. Oh well.  The point is that PoE is free to play and NOT pay to win, like this's one of the very few games that you can literally play start to end for free without microtransactions at all and they don't penalize you for it. You just get nice bonus stuff for paying, but you never feel like you're missing out because you didn't. The mechanics are exceptionally well designed and quite clever, the game is fast and fun, and works great with friends. It's built with hardcore diablo players in mind, and as you get farther into the game, it keeps introducing more and more new elements to the game play to keep things interested, even for high level players. It has a bit of a high skill floor for new players, so it can be a little rough to get started, but if you like having lots of stuff to keep learning to keep you interested that's not really that big of a problem.  In short, for the type of game they're building... it's pretty much perfect. Path of Exile scratches exactly the itch that Diablo 3 didn't. It just isn't really ideal for newbies is all.

[sellout review for the steam sale badge] Premise: Path of Exile is a dark-fantasy ARPG, heavily inspired by Diablo 2. It has a deep customization system, allowing you to create any kind of character you want.  Introduction: I could complain how in recent years the game got faster and how that's not cool, how the balance is always slightly off and all, but generally..  Execution: this game's awesome. This game is a sandbox for all the creepy characters you can make with it. Witch hurling fireballs? Not hipster enough? How about a witch that burns her surrounding, but herself along with it. You realize you better do a different class for that, but your Skyrim sense of 'i won't let that mountain defeat me' is tingling. So you get your resistances over the usual cap with special items, you get tons of regen, maybe you can do it as an Energy Shield instead, you figure it out. It works, it actually works, holy molly. Then you think to yourself... There's this item that let's me using a Vaal skill (like a MOBA ultimate), if i could sustain it, elemental damage would heal me instead... And there's this really obscure item that reduces my elemental resistances to zero, so... You break the game. Now in proper conditions your character is immortal. Well done. So a crazy idea pops into your head, and you roll with it. Game can be played both casually and in hardcore modes. There's a racing scene (short events, mostly who clears Act 1 the fastest for example), for which you get actual rewards. This game has the content.  Problems: some balancing problems, that are quite understandable, especially if you consider the game's developed by a small studio from New Zealand. This is definitely the part where i should go bonkers over performance problems. Glad to say tha with DX11 beta client they are pretty much gone and the game even looks better. There are some glitches, Ubisoft-style object geometry glitches, but i can smell the bright, bright future. This was holding the game back more than anything else.  Business model: I feel you really need to buy more stash tabs through microtransactions to have *real* fun, but considering how much time you can get out of this game, it's worth it. Note: better buy a supporter pack, keep your points until the stash tab bundles are discounted, then but them.  Overall: it's worth leveling at least one character. This type of game's is not for everyone, but you might end up getting hooked. I seriously suggest watching some streams to learn more about the game, the community is pretty great.. Unless you're trying to trade with them, but oh well. I'm really glad this game exists.

I've played this game since before act 2 was released. i have probobly 800 hours combined with steam.  Path of Exile(PoE) is an isometric hack n slash in the style of diablo 2.   The game takes place on the island of Wraeclast where you are marooned. The story may seem cobbled together, but it is very fragmented. Its kind of like dark souls. You find scraps of info on the history and the people of the island and how it has come to how it is now. If your not into that style of storytelling(I certainly am not), you can just go to the wiki for the game and learn everything about the world you are in. It gives you a sense of purpose when you understand how royally screwed you are when you release what is going on, and makes the struggle a lot more personal.  The gameplay is tight and fast. Very fast. To fast sometimes. Its visceral as hordes explode into ash or fall as ice cubes around you. The most satisfying combat in any hack n slash, in my opinion. There is so much customization of abilities and builds that a quick peek at the forum will have you dumbfounded at the lengths people go to on how to get a level 5 bow to work against endgame bosses and the highest level content available.   The economy does away with gold. No one uses it on this island. Its just shiny floppy metal that doesn't kill the monsters infesting this island. And this game and the people in the world live to kill everything. And in a game where you armor decides if you get cut in half or you sword decides if you cut them in half first, what better economy is there than gear? Well, items called 'Orbs' that can improve gear. There are various orbs that you will find in the game that can alter the properties of items, potentially turning a clunky old necklace into god tier amulet that defines your playstyle. Orbs vary in rarity and in such, value. You can trade with players, using orbs as your currency for item exchanges and websites like Poe.trade facilitate that. Allowing instantanious item searches to find that sword with all the right stats for the right price. You just message the owner ingame and trade your currency for the sword.   Co-op is easy, too. A simple party system will allow you to hop into the world of the party leader and experience the world together, back to back surrounded by angry skeletons. Loot system in the game is tied to indivual players which prevents theft if your in public parties. Options for free4all and round robin, too.   The game very much falls into the easy to learn, hard to master catagory. If your looking for diablo-like hack n slash, then this is at the top of the list. No other hack n slash, not even the 60$ Diablo 3 title, comes close to the depth of gameplay and competency of the endgame system.   10/10. Would buy. Why can't I buy?  Just buy yourself some stash tabs. Support this developer if you enjoy the game.

The game has been going in a new direction the last year and a bit, they've rapidly been gaining more concurrent players so I do not blame them for sticking to what they're currently doing.  Since the 2.0 patch (Ascendancy expansion) there has been a gradual power-creep. 2.0 introduced subclasses called ascendancies, these subclasses were incredibly powerful with no downside despite this massive buff we did not see any real retuning of monster health to compensate for this massive buff. 2.0 also buffed the drop chance of the rarest unique items in the game by 400% while many will disagree that this is a bad thing I believe it is as it lets people making insanely strong builds quicker and with less grinding involved. As the game grew new leagues brought in new ways to make currency, due to this the rate at which you gain currency has increased exponentially meaning you can make an incredibly strong character is much less time..  Over the next few months there was little to no nerfs despite the fact that the majority of the content was being trivialized. We then saw a massive buff to energy shield making the amount you could get much higher, Most people could hit 10000 ES without a huge investment, some going 12000+ This is an insane amount of health and further trivialized content.  I implore anyone who disagrees to check videos from two years ago vs today. Check Darkee's poison mines build that made the hardest content in the game at the time(Uber atziri) completely trivial. Also check mathil's current blade flurry guide. His tactic for defeating the new bosses(Breach lords) is to do so much damage quickly that they die before doing anything.   The game has become zip around with a movement skill one hit a pack of mobs loot and move on. Due to GGG catering to this clear-speed meta mob damage was buffed meaning if you play a slow non-meta build everything is insanely dangerous even white mobs. The best defense has become kill something but it can do anything. The only things that get nerfed are builds that a huge amount of people play, other things are rarely touched at all.   GGG is an amazing company who talk to the community a lot. It's nice to see the game grow so much and obviously this shift to a more casual tone has helped the game grow greatly, it's just not for everyone. If you're looking for difficult content you're going to have to go out of your way to find it.

A (truly) free to play hack n' slash / arpg game, set in the land of Wraeclast, it can't but not remind at least a bit of Diablo series. It has all the standard stuff you'd expect from a game this type such as waypoints, portal & identify scrolls etc. But the greatest thing this game has (other than the no pay to win policy) is the endless customization of your characters AND of your gear. You can make a melee character out of your archer/spellcaster (and vice versa), who says a witch can't have a two-handed sword and/or be a tank? There is no techtree in which you select abilities, no, you get skills as rewards and use whichever ones you want on your character. You can make your own gear, and remake it. The possibilities are endless and that is what makes this game a true gem.
